This paper adds WordNet word pair relations to an existing natural language inference model. Synonyms, antonyms, and non-synonymous sister terms in the ontology are represented using indicator features. Hyponymy and hypernymy are represented using path length features. These features are used to modify inter sentence attention, the final post-attention word representations, and the pooling operation used to aggregate the final sentence representations prior to inference. All of these three additions help, especially in the low data learning scenario. When all of the SNLI training data is used this approach adds 0.6% accuracy on the SNLI 3-way classification task. 

I think that the integration of structured knowledge representations into neural models is a great avenue of investigation. And I'm glad to see that WordNet helps. But very little was done to investigate different ways in which these data can be integrated. The authors mention work on knowledge base embeddings and there has been plenty of work on learning WordNet embeddings. An obvious avenue of exploration would compare the use of these to the use of the indicator features in this paper. Another avenue of exploration is the integration of more resources such as VerbNet, propbank, WikiData etc. An approach that works with all of these would be much more impressive as it would need to handle a much more diverse feature space than the 4 inter-dependent features introduced here.

Questions for authors:

Is the WordNet hierarchy bounded at a depth of 8? If so please state this and if not, what is the motivation of your hypernymy and hyponymy features?
LLM_1:
This paper incorporates WordNet relations into an NLI model, using indicator features for synonyms, antonyms, and sister terms, and path length features for hyponymy/hypernymy. These features modify inter-sentence attention, post-attention word representations, and pooling before inference. The additions improve performance, especially in low-data settings, yielding a 0.6% accuracy gain on SNLI with full training data.

Integrating structured knowledge into neural models is promising, and WordNet’s utility is encouraging. However, alternative integration methods are underexplored. Prior work on knowledge base and WordNet embeddings could be compared to the indicator features used here. Incorporating additional resources like VerbNet, PropBank, or Wikidata would also be valuable, as handling a broader, more diverse feature space would be more impactful.

Questions for authors:

Is the WordNet hierarchy depth capped at 8? If so, please clarify; if not, explain the motivation for your hypernymy/hyponymy features.
LLM_2:
**

This study integrates WordNet relations into a natural language inference (NLI) model by employing indicator features for synonyms, antonyms, and sister terms, along with path length features for hyponymy/hypernymy relationships. These features are applied to modify inter-sentence attention mechanisms, post-attention word representations, and pooling layers prior to inference. The proposed enhancements lead to improved model performance, particularly in low-data scenarios, achieving a 0.6% accuracy increase on the SNLI dataset with full training data.

The integration of structured knowledge into neural models represents a promising direction, and the effective use of WordNet in this context is encouraging. However, alternative methods for knowledge integration remain underexplored. Future work could benefit from comparing the indicator features used here with prior approaches involving knowledge base embeddings or WordNet embeddings. Additionally, incorporating supplementary resources such as VerbNet, PropBank, or Wikidata could further enhance the model, as expanding the feature space to include more diverse linguistic and semantic information would likely yield greater impact.

**Questions for the Authors:**

1. Is the depth of the WordNet hierarchy capped at 8 in your implementation? If so, please provide clarification; if not, could you explain the rationale behind the design of your hypernymy/hyponymy features?

Ella, who had earlier escaped from Kate and Tyson Burns-Green's West Mersea garden, was spotted swimming to Ray Island and Packing Shed Island before eventually being rescued on Sunday.
The Blackwater Veterinary Surgery said she was 95% dehydrated.
For more on this and other Essex stories
During her rescue by boatmen from Mersea, she plunged into the water again and and attempted to swim towards Tollesbury.
Hundreds watched and applauded as nine-year-old Ella was brought ashore and reunited with her owners.

"It all culminated on Sunday evening when a family spotted a black Labrador on Ray Island and they rang my husband.

### Black Labrador Ella Rescued After Dramatic Escape on Mersea Island

**Mersea Island** – A black Labrador named Ella made headlines this weekend after fleeing into the waters surrounding Mersea Island following a collision with a car on Thursday. After escaping from the garden of her owners, Kate and Tyson Burns-Green, Ella was spotted swimming toward Ray Island and Packing Shed Island before her eventual rescue on Sunday.

The Blackwater Veterinary Surgery reported that Ella was found to be severely dehydrated, with a dehydration level of 95%. 

During her rescue, Ella unexpectedly jumped back into the water, attempting to swim to Tollesbury. A crowd of hundreds gathered to cheer as the nine-year-old dog was finally brought ashore and joyfully reunited with her relieved owners.

Mrs. Burns-Green recounted the frantic search for Ella, noting that appeals for information spread quickly across social media after the dog went missing. "Although she loves swimming, she usually asks before going into the water," she explained.

The situation intensified when a family spotted a black Labrador on Ray Island and promptly contacted her husband. Their dog nudged Ella from her hiding spot in the bushes, prompting her to swim toward Packing Shed Island. Once there, she jumped into the water again, but two boats managed to corner her and safely bring her back to shore just as the sun set. "I was totally overwhelmed by the amount of love and support out there," Mrs. Burns-Green expressed gratefully. 

Ella's story serves as a reminder of the bond between pets and their owners, and the community's willingness to come together in times of need.

Ethan Johnson died from a combination of symptoms after his faeces was found in his mother's waters before his birth. His mother said: "I don't feel anybody took charge. It was chaos."
The inquest heard there were problems contacting the midwife and senior staff before the caesarean section delivery.
The coroner said he would write a report for the hospital to respond to.
He said there was a "lost opportunity" to deliver Ethan earlier and treat him.
Ethan was born on Sunday 4 January - four days after his mother Claire Johnson, of Bletchley, first reported having contractions.
The inquest heard the midwife assigned to her was not informed that Ms Johnson had arrived on the Sunday and there were delays in reviewing Ethan's heart rate.
Staff called for a consultant at 12:15 GMT when a scan indicated abnormalities, but there were issues contacting senior staff and there was another emergency in the delivery unit that day.
Ethan was delivered at about 13:30 GMT.
The cause of his death the following day was recorded as perinatal asphyxia and meconium aspiration.
Thomas Osborne, coroner, said: "The delay... resulted in a lost opportunity to deliver him earlier and render further medical treatment."
In his narrative verdict he said he was concerned about "a lack of leadership" and would submit a report to the hospital, which it had 56 days to respond to.
Ms Johnson told the inquest: "If there were mistakes made, then they need to be honest about that. I don't want more babies to die."
A hospital investigation concluded that Ethan's death was unavoidable, the inquest heard.
Speaking after the inquest, clinical director Ed Neale said he was "confident" changes had been made at the hospital which would satisfy the coroner.
"We have made a number of changes to the leadership processes, we have a new matron and head of midwifery since Ethan's death," he said.

Coroner Thomas Osborne noted a "lost opportunity" to deliver Ethan earlier and provide necessary treatment. Ethan was born on January 4, four days after Claire reported contractions. The assigned midwife was not informed of Claire's arrival, leading to delays in monitoring Ethan's heart rate.

A consultant was called at 12:15 GMT when a scan showed abnormalities, but there were issues reaching senior staff due to another emergency in the delivery unit. Ethan was delivered around 13:30 GMT. His death the following day was attributed to perinatal asphyxia and meconium aspiration.

Osborne criticized the "lack of leadership" and announced plans to submit a report to the hospital, which has 56 days to respond. Claire Johnson urged honesty about any mistakes, stating, "I don't want more babies to die." A hospital investigation concluded that Ethan's death was unavoidable.

After the inquest, clinical director Ed Neale expressed confidence in the changes made at the hospital, including new leadership in midwifery.
LLM_2:
**Inquest Reveals Coordination Issues Surrounding Infant's Death**

Ethan Johnson tragically passed away due to a combination of complications linked to his birth, which was preceded by his mother, Claire Johnson, experiencing meconium in her amniotic fluid. Claire voiced her dissatisfaction with the situation, saying, “I don't feel anybody took charge. It was chaos.”

During the inquest, it emerged that there were significant challenges in reaching the midwife and senior medical staff prior to Ethan’s caesarean section. Coroner Thomas Osborne highlighted a "lost opportunity" to facilitate an earlier delivery that could have ensured Ethan received timely medical intervention. Ethan was born on January 4, four days after Claire had reported experiencing contractions. Unfortunately, the midwife assigned to Claire was not notified of her arrival, which resulted in delays in monitoring Ethan's heart rate.

A consultant was called at 12:15 GMT after a scan indicated irregularities, but attempts to contact senior staff were hindered by another emergency occurring in the delivery unit. Ethan was finally delivered at around 13:30 GMT. He died the following day, with the cause attributed to perinatal asphyxia and meconium aspiration.

Coroner Osborne criticized the "lack of leadership" during the incident and announced his intention to submit a report to the hospital, which will have 56 days to respond. Claire Johnson emphasized the importance of transparency regarding any mistakes, stating, “I don’t want more babies to die.” A hospital investigation concluded that the circumstances surrounding Ethan’s death were unavoidable.

Following the inquest, clinical director Ed Neale expressed optimism about the changes implemented at the hospital, including new leadership within the midwifery team.

As reflected in its name, Kolmogorov Growth takes inspiration from Kolmogorov complexity and the growth function. Conceptually, KG measures the size of the simplest class of functions that a given function f belongs to. The main innovation seems to be the min_i operator, which restricts our attention to the simplest function class. KG by itself is obviously not computable, but the paper proposes an interesting way to approximate it.

The generalization bound in section 3.1 is not particularly surprising. In a sense, the proof for this bound is embedded in the definition of KG itself. Still, I think this is an interesting approach to bounding the generalization error.

Network-to-network regularization is motivated by the results in section 3.1, which show that functions that can be approximated well by small networks will have low KG. N2N trains a small student network and a large teacher network to output similar predictions to each other. This makes the student learn from the teacher, while the teacher is regularized by the simpler function of the student. The paper also considers a multi-level version where a sequence of progressively smaller networks are trained with the same loss.

N2N hinges on the implicit assumption that smaller networks have smaller hypothesis spaces and thus learn simpler functions. While this is likely true in a strict sense, many results with neural networks show that small networks have surprisingly strong expressive power. For example, works on knowledge distillation show that minimal networks can achieve accuracy close to that of a large teacher, and [1] shows that a rather small network can fit random labels. I think this implicit assumption and its limitations should be discussed a bit more in the paper.

Experiments show that N2N acts as an effective regularizer and that N2N regularization indeed reduces the KG bound. It would have been interesting to additionally include the generalization gap in Figure 2 so that the KG bound can be compared with it.

There may be a more direct correspondence between Kolmogorov complexity and KG. In KG’s definition (section 3), you essentially construct a short two-part program for describing the function f where you first describe the function class F and then specify f within F. I wouldn’t be surprised if the two concepts can be shown to have a stronger relation than KC simply acting as “indirect motivation” for KG (line 140). I think this is an exciting direction for future work.

[1] Understanding deep learning requires rethinking generalization, Chiyuan Zhang, Samy Bengio, Moritz Hardt, Benjamin Recht, Oriol Vinyals
LLM_1:
Kolmogorov Growth (KG) draws inspiration from Kolmogorov complexity and the growth function, measuring the size of the simplest function class containing a given function \( f \). Its key innovation is the \(\min_i\) operator, which focuses on the simplest class. While KG itself is not computable, the paper offers a promising approximation method.

The generalization bound in Section 3.1 follows naturally from KG’s definition, though the approach to bounding generalization error remains interesting.

Network-to-network (N2N) regularization is motivated by Section 3.1, which links low KG to functions well-approximated by small networks. N2N trains a small student and a large teacher to produce similar predictions, allowing the student to learn from the teacher while the teacher is regularized by the student’s simpler function. A multi-level variant trains a sequence of progressively smaller networks with the same loss.

N2N assumes smaller networks have smaller hypothesis spaces and thus learn simpler functions. While plausible, neural network literature shows small networks can be highly expressive—e.g., in knowledge distillation or fitting random labels [1]. This assumption and its limitations deserve further discussion.

Experiments confirm N2N acts as an effective regularizer and reduces the KG bound. Including the generalization gap in Figure 2 would help compare it directly with the bound.

A stronger link may exist between Kolmogorov complexity and KG. In KG’s definition (Section 3), a short two-part program describes \( f \) by first specifying the function class \( F \), then \( f \) within \( F \). Exploring a deeper connection beyond indirect motivation (line 140) is an exciting direction for future work.

[1] Zhang et al., “Understanding deep learning requires rethinking generalization.”
LLM_2:
The paper introduces **Kolmogorov Growth (KG)**, a measure inspired by Kolmogorov complexity and the growth function, which quantifies the size of the simplest function class containing a given function \( f \). A central innovation is the \(\min_i\) operator, which isolates the minimal such class. Although KG itself is not computable, the authors propose a practical approximation method.  

The generalization bound in Section 3.1 follows directly from the definition of KG, yet the overall approach to bounding generalization error remains conceptually interesting.  

Building on this, the authors propose **Network-to-Network (N2N) regularization**, motivated by the link (Section 3.1) between low KG and functions well-approximated by compact networks. N2N trains a small student network and a large teacher network to produce similar predictions, enabling the student to learn from the teacher while the teacher is regularized by the student’s simpler function. A multi-level extension trains a sequence of progressively smaller networks using the same loss.  

**Strengths**  
- Experiments demonstrate that N2N acts as an effective regularizer and reduces the KG bound.  
- The connection between Kolmogorov complexity and generalization is a compelling direction.  

**Suggestions for Improvement**  

1. **Clarify the assumption underlying N2N.**  
   N2N relies on the premise that smaller networks inherently learn simpler functions. While intuitive, the neural network literature shows that even compact architectures can be highly expressive—e.g., in knowledge distillation or when fitting random labels [1]. A more nuanced discussion of this assumption and its limitations would strengthen the methodological grounding.  

2. **Strengthen empirical evaluation.**  
   Including the **generalization gap** (train vs. test error) in Figure 2 would allow a direct comparison with the theoretical bound and help assess how tightly the bound aligns with practical performance.  

3. **Deepen the theoretical connection to Kolmogorov complexity.**  
   In the definition of KG (Section 3), a two-part code first specifies the function class \( F \), then identifies \( f \) within \( F \). The current link to Kolmogorov complexity remains somewhat indirect (line 140). Exploring a more formal or explicit connection—perhaps through the lens of two-part description length—could be a valuable direction for future theoretical work.  

**Reference**  
[1] Zhang et al., “Understanding deep learning requires rethinking generalization.”  

---

**Overall**  
The paper presents a novel measure (KG) and an innovative regularization method (N2N) with solid empirical results. Addressing the points above—especially clarifying the assumptions of N2N and enriching the evaluation—would further solidify the contribution. The proposed bridge between Kolmogorov-style complexity and generalization is promising and merits deeper exploration.

human: The inhabitants of the British Isles have been drinking ale since the Bronze Age, but it was with the arrival of the Roman Empire in its shores in the 1st Century, and the construction of the Roman road networks that the first inns, called tabernae, in which travellers could obtain refreshment began to appear. After the departure of Roman authority in the 5th Century and the fall of the Romano-British kingdoms, the Anglo-Saxons established alehouses that grew out of domestic dwellings, the Anglo-Saxon alewife would put a green bush up on a pole to let people know her brew was ready. These alehouses quickly evolved into meeting houses for the folk to socially congregate, gossip and arrange mutual help within their communities. Herein lies the origin of the modern public house, or "Pub" as it is colloquially called in England. They rapidly spread across the Kingdom, becoming so commonplace that in 965 King Edgar decreed that there should be no more than one alehouse per village.
LLM_1: The inhabitants of the British Isles have consumed ale since the Bronze Age, but the first inns—known as *tabernae*—emerged with the Roman conquest in the 1st century and the development of Roman roads, providing refreshment for travelers. Following the collapse of Roman authority and the Romano-British kingdoms in the 5th century, the Anglo-Saxons established alehouses originating from private homes. An alewife would signal ready brews by placing a bush on a pole. These alehouses soon became community hubs for socializing, gossip, and organizing mutual aid, forming the foundation of the modern public house, or "pub." Their proliferation was so rapid that by 965, King Edgar limited villages to one alehouse each.
LLM_2:
---

Alcoholic beverages, particularly ale, have been consumed in the British Isles since at least the Bronze Age. However, the earliest establishments resembling inns—known as *tabernae*—appeared during the Roman occupation of Britain in the 1st century CE, coinciding with the construction of an extensive network of Roman roads. These roadside establishments provided food, drink, and lodging for travelers and officials.

Following the decline of Roman authority and the collapse of the Romano-British political order in the 5th century, such formal structures largely disappeared. In their place, the incoming Anglo-Saxons developed informal drinking venues known as alehouses, typically operated from private dwellings. These were often run by women known as "alewives," who would signal that fresh brew was available by suspending a bush—commonly referred to as a "bushel" or simply a "bush"—on a pole outside the dwelling, giving rise to the phrase "good ale is under the bush."

Over time, alehouses evolved into central social institutions within local communities, serving not only as places for drinking but also for exchanging news, conducting informal business, and organizing mutual aid. This communal function laid the groundwork for the development of the modern public house, commonly known as the "pub." The rapid spread of alehouses prompted regulatory responses; by 965, King Edgar of England issued decrees restricting villages to a single licensed alehouse, reflecting early efforts to control both the quantity and conduct associated with such establishments.

---

`` There's been a murder. I do n't believe it. Someone reported a murder.'' 
 
 `` A murder?'' I asked. 
 
 `` You know, a premeditated killing. Deliberately ending the life of your fellow man. The thing in the back of your training manual that you only read once because you were never going to need it.'' My partner explained. 
 
 `` That's... You...'' I felt sick just thinking about it. *'' How? `` * 
 
 Between the brain tweaks and good old-fashioned cultural conditioning, most people could barely *consider* the idea of attacking a fellow citizen. I knew I'd be dealing with lawbreakers, but this was something that was just unheard of. 
 
 `` I know, it's a hell of a thing to sic on the new guy. But this is our case whether we like it or not.'' 
 
 Officer Milo patted the me on the back. `` Come on. It's still just a crime. We find out who did it, and we arrest them.'' 
 
 We climbed into the car and rode in silence. I tried to imagine what sort of mind could do such a thing. What sort of person would be able to cut a throat or crush a skull without being crushed by guilt? Was he consumed by some emotion that it overcame his conditioning? Some glitch in his brain that turned off his sense of reason? Could his mind even still function, knowing what he'd done? 
 
 `` Do you think,'' I asked nervously, `` He'd be able to, um... resist arrest?'' The phrase was almost foreign to me, it showed up in legal textbooks and nowhere else. Nobody resisted the police. Once we found the criminal, our work was done. 
 
 `` He might.'' My partner said grimly. `` When we find this guy, we'll ask him politely, but we might have to use force.'' 
 
 He shook his head. `` I never thought I'd actually need that training in this day and age.'' 
 
 `` Training?'' 
 
 `` When I was in the academy, I was a big history buff, so I read about an old martial art called'Arrest and Control Techniques.' About five hundred years ago, they invented it to restrain people by force without killing them. Would you believe, that was actually considered good police work back then?'' 
 
 `` Really?'' 
 
 `` Yeah. Because at least you were n't shooting them, right? Life was brutal in the early 2000s. Anyway, long story short, the academy still has the old holo-training manuals for use of violence, so I watched one. Nasty stuff.'' 
 
 I grimaced. I was n't into that sort of thing. I had joined the force because I wanted to solve mysteries, not because I had sick fantasies about beating people up. 
 
 We pulled up at the crime scene, a tall hab-block. An ambulance was already there, and I saw a woman sitting on a bench, a soma patch pressed on her arm to calm her down. She must have been the one to find the body, poor girl. 
 
 We walked upstairs and into the apartment, following her directions. Bile rose in my throat as I stared at the body, and even my more hardened partner turned pale. 
 
 The victim was covered in long, bloody gashes, and the hardwood floor was covered in dark-brown spatters where it had dried. Lurid patterns of blood surrounded him, gruesome smears and sprays as if someone had tried to fingerpaint in blood. So much blood. Who could have... 
 
 `` Hey, rookie, you still with me?'' 
 
 I nodded. `` Just... Getting my bearings.'' 
 
 `` In all my years on force, I have n't seen anything like this.'' 
 
 `` You do n't seem affected.'' 
 
 He sighed heavily. `` I do n't know why that is. Not everyone's wired the same way, I suppose.'' 
 
 `` Do you think that's what this was? Someone who's just... wired the wrong way? Can someone really be born this messed up?'' 
 
 `` Not for the past century, as far as I know.'' 
 
 `` Then we've got two mysteries to solve.'' I reached up and flipped on my visor, and the bloody corpse was covered by the soft blue glow of my forensic scanner. `` I'll scan the scene, can you check the hab's cameras?'' 
 
 `` You sure you do n't want to do that the other way around? You do n't have to make yourself look tough in front of me.'' 
 
 I shook my head. `` No. I need to handle this. I'm not going to be dead weight on this case.'' 
 
 `` Suit yourself.'' He turned away from the body and pulled out his tablet. 
 
 I turned my attention back to the body. I had a feeling this would n't be the only horror I'd see on this case.

There’s been a murder. I don’t believe it. Someone reported a killing.”

“A murder?” I asked.

“You know—premeditated. Deliberate. Ending another person’s life. The thing buried in the back of your training manual, the one you skimmed once because you never thought you’d need it,” my partner said.

“That’s… you…” My stomach twisted. “How?”

Between neural conditioning and generations of cultural reinforcement, violence against others was nearly unthinkable. We were built to obey, to serve, to *not* harm. I joined the force to solve puzzles, not face horrors like this.

“I know,” he said. “Terrible way to start. But it’s our case now.”

Officer Milo clapped me on the back. “Come on. It’s still just a crime. We find who did it. We arrest them.”

We drove in silence. I tried to imagine the mind behind such an act—someone who could slit a throat, crush a skull, and walk away unbroken. Was it rage? A glitch in their brain mod? Could anyone live with that weight?

“Do you think,” I asked, voice tight, “he might… resist arrest?”

The words felt alien. No one resisted. Not anymore. Once we identified a suspect, it was over.

“He might,” my partner replied grimly. “We’ll ask politely. But we may have to use force.”

He shook his head. “Never thought I’d need that training in this age.”

“Training?”

“When I was at the academy, I dug into history. Found old holo-manuals on something called ‘Arrest and Control Techniques’—a five-hundred-year-old martial art for subduing people without killing them. Can you believe it? Back then, *that* was considered humane. The early 2000s were brutal.”

“Seriously?”

“Yeah. At least you weren’t shooting them, right? Anyway, I watched one. Nasty stuff.”

I grimaced. That wasn’t why I became a cop.

We arrived at the hab-block. An ambulance idled outside. A woman sat on a bench, soma patch glowing on her arm, eyes hollow. She must’ve found the body.

We followed her directions upstairs. The apartment door stood open.

I saw the corpse—and nearly retched.

Blood everywhere. Long, jagged cuts carved across the victim’s skin. Dark spatters crusted the hardwood, smeared into grotesque arcs, like someone had painted with their fingers. Too much blood. Who could do this?

“Rookie. You still with me?”

I nodded. “Just… getting my bearings.”

“In all my years, I’ve never seen anything like this.”

“You seem calm.”

He exhaled. “Don’t know why. People are wired differently, I guess.”

“Could that be it? Someone born broken? Can someone even *be* like that anymore?”

“Not in the last hundred years.”

“Then we’ve got two mysteries,” I said, flipping on my visor. The blue glow of my forensic scanner washed over the body. “I’ll scan the scene. Check the hab’s cameras?”

“You sure? You don’t have to prove anything to me.”

“No. I need to handle this. I won’t be dead weight.”

“Suit yourself.” He turned away, pulled out his tablet.

I looked back at the body.

This wouldn’t be the last horror I’d see.

There’s been a murder.  
I don’t believe it.  
Someone reported a killing.”

“A *murder*?” I echoed.

“You know,” my partner said, voice low and deliberate. “Premeditated. Intentional. The cold severing of one life by another. That dark little clause buried at the back of your training manual—the one you skimmed once, dismissed forever, because you never thought you’d need it.”

“That’s… you…” My stomach knotted, bile rising. “How?”

Violence had been engineered out of us. Between neural conditioning and centuries of cultural shaping, to harm another was nearly unthinkable. We were built to serve, to obey, to *not* destroy. I joined the force for the puzzles—the elegant logic of missing things, broken systems, encrypted trails. Not this. Never this.

“I know,” he said quietly. “Hell of a way to start. But it’s ours now.”

Officer Milo clapped me on the shoulder—too hard, maybe, or just hard enough. “Come on. It’s still just a crime. We find who did it. We bring them in.”

We drove in silence. Outside, the city pulsed in neon and shadow, but inside the cruiser, time thickened. I tried to imagine the mind behind such an act—someone who could slit a throat, crush a skull, then walk away whole. Was it rage? A fracture in their brain mod? Some ancient flaw no one remembered how to name? Could anyone live with that weight and still call themselves human?

“Do you think…” I began, my voice tight, brittle, “…he might resist arrest?”

The words tasted foreign. No one resisted. Not anymore. Once we identified a suspect, it was over. Compliance was coded into bone and synapse.

“He might,” my partner replied, eyes fixed ahead. “We’ll ask politely. But we may have to use force.”

He shook his head slowly, as if dislodging dust from an old memory. “Never thought I’d need that training in this age.”

“Training?”

“When I was at the academy, I dug into the archives. Found holo-manuals on something called ‘Arrest and Control Techniques’—a five-hundred-year-old martial art designed to subdue people without killing them.” He let out a dry laugh. “Can you believe it? Back then, *that* was considered humane. The early 2000s were brutal.”

“Seriously?”

“Yeah. At least you weren’t shooting them, right?” He shrugged. “Anyway, I watched one session. Nasty stuff.”

I grimaced. That wasn’t why I became a cop.

We arrived at the hab-block. An ambulance idled at the curb, its lights muted, respectful. On a bench nearby, a woman sat motionless, a soma patch glowing faintly on her forearm, her eyes empty—vacant in the way only shock can hollow out.

She must’ve found the body.

We followed her directions upstairs. The apartment door stood ajar, like a mouth left open in silent scream.

Then I saw it.

And nearly retched.

Blood everywhere. Long, jagged cuts carved into the victim’s skin—deep, erratic, almost artistic in their horror. Dark spatters crusted the hardwood floor, flung into grotesque arcs, smeared as if someone had painted with their fingers. Too much blood. Too much *intention*. Who could do this? And more terrifying—how could they live with themselves after?

“Rookie,” my partner said, steady. “You still with me?”

I nodded. Swallowed. “Just… getting my bearings.”

“In all my years,” he murmured, stepping carefully around the stains, “I’ve never seen anything like this.”

“You seem calm.”

He exhaled, long and slow. “Don’t know why. People are wired differently, I guess.”

“Could that be it? Someone born broken? Can someone even *be* like that anymore?”

“Not in the last hundred years.”

“Then we’ve got two mysteries,” I said, flipping on my visor. The blue glow of my forensic scanner washed over the corpse, casting sharp shadows across the walls. “I’ll scan the scene. You check the hab’s cameras?”

“You sure?” He turned, studying me. “You don’t have to prove anything to me.”

“No,” I said, firmer now. “I need to handle this. I won’t be dead weight.”

“Suit yourself.” He turned away, pulled out his tablet.

I looked back at the body.

Something inside me shifted—something quiet and irreversible.

This wouldn’t be the last horror I’d see.

But it would be the first I truly understood.

### Notes on the Polishing:
- **Tone & Atmosphere**: Heightened the noir-tinged, introspective mood common in speculative fiction. Emphasized sensory details (light, sound, texture) to ground the reader.
- **Pacing**: Broke dialogue and action into tighter beats for dramatic effect, especially during the discovery of the body.
- **Character Voice**: Deepened the internal conflict of the narrator—highlighting their idealism, shock, and dawning resolve.
- **Language Precision**: Replaced functional phrasing (“we drove in silence”) with more evocative alternatives that suggest emotional weight.
- **Thematic Reinforcement**: Strengthened the contrast between a peaceful society and sudden violence, making the murder feel even more transgressive.

human: Epilepsy is a serious brain disorder characterized by recurrent unprovoked seizures. Approximately two-thirds of seizures can be controlled with antiepileptic medications (Kwan 2000). For some of the others, surgery can completely eliminate or significantly reduce the occurrence of disabling seizures. Localization of epileptogenic areas for resective surgery is far from perfect, and new tools are being investigated to more accurately localize the epileptogenic zone (the zone of the brain where the seizures begin) and improve the likelihood of freedom from postsurgical seizures. Recordings of pathological high-frequency oscillations (HFOs) may be one such tool.To assess the ability of HFOs to improve the outcomes of epilepsy surgery by helping to identify more accurately the epileptogenic areas of the brain.We searched the Cochrane Epilepsy Group Specialized Register (15 April 2013), the Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials (CENTRAL) in The Cochrane Library (2013, Issue 3), MEDLINE (Ovid) (1946 to 15 April 2013), CINAHL (EBSCOhost) (15 April 2013), Web of Knowledge (Thomson Reuters) (15 April 2013), www.clinicaltrials.gov (15 April 2013), and the World Health Organization International Clinical Trials Registry Platform (15 April 2013).We included studies that provided information on the outcomes of epilepsy surgery at at least six months and which used high-frequency oscillations in making decisions about epilepsy surgery.The primary outcome of the review was the Engel Class Outcome System. Secondary outcomes were responder rate, International League Against Epilepsy (ILAE) epilepsy surgery outcome, frequency of adverse events from any source and quality of life outcomes. We intended to analyse outcomes via an aggregated data fixed-effect model meta-analysis.Two studies met the inclusion criteria. Both studies were small non-randomised trials, with no control group and no blinding. The quality of evidence for all outcomes was very low. The combination of these two studies resulted in 11 participants who prospectively used ictal HFOs for epilepsy surgery decision making. Results of the postsurgical seizure freedom Engel class I to IV outcome were determined over a period of 12 to 38 months (average 23.4 months) and indicated that six participants had an Engel class I outcome (seizure freedom), two had class II (rare disabling seizures), three had class III (worthwhile improvement). No adverse effects were reported. Neither study compared surgical results guided by HFOs versus surgical results guided without HFOs.

However, localizing epileptogenic areas for resective surgery remains challenging, prompting investigations into new tools for better identification of the epileptogenic zone, where seizures originate. One such tool is the recording of pathological high-frequency oscillations (HFOs). This review aims to evaluate HFOs' effectiveness in enhancing epilepsy surgery outcomes by improving the localization of epileptogenic areas. We searched several databases, including the Cochrane Epilepsy Group Specialized Register, Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials, MEDLINE, CINAHL, Web of Knowledge, clinicaltrials.gov, and the WHO International Clinical Trials Registry Platform, for studies reporting on epilepsy surgery outcomes after at least six months, using HFOs for surgical decision-making. The primary outcome was the Engel Class Outcome System, with secondary outcomes including responder rate, ILAE surgery outcomes, adverse event frequency, and quality of life measures. Data were intended to be analyzed using a fixed-effect model meta-analysis. Two studies met the inclusion criteria, both being small non-randomized trials without control groups or blinding, yielding very low-quality evidence. The combined analysis involved 11 participants who utilized ictal HFOs for surgical decisions. Over 12 to 38 months (average 23.4 months), six participants achieved Engel class I (seizure freedom), two reached class II (rare disabling seizures), and three attained class III (worthwhile improvement). No adverse effects were reported. Neither study compared surgical outcomes with HFO guidance to those without.
LLM_2:
**Abstract**

Epilepsy is a prevalent neurological disorder characterized by recurrent unprovoked seizures, with approximately two-thirds of cases manageable through antiepileptic pharmacotherapy (Kwan, 2000). For patients unresponsive to medication, surgical intervention may lead to complete or significant seizure reduction. Nonetheless, accurately localizing epileptogenic zones for resective surgery poses considerable challenges, necessitating the exploration of novel methodologies for enhanced identification of seizure origins. One promising approach involves the recording of pathological high-frequency oscillations (HFOs). This review seeks to assess the role of HFOs in improving surgical outcomes in epilepsy by facilitating the localization of epileptogenic regions. A comprehensive literature search was conducted across multiple databases, including the Cochrane Epilepsy Group Specialized Register, Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials, MEDLINE, CINAHL, Web of Knowledge, clinicaltrials.gov, and the WHO International Clinical Trials Registry Platform, targeting studies that reported on surgical outcomes related to epilepsy following a minimum follow-up period of six months and utilized HFOs for surgical decision-making. The primary outcome evaluated was the Engel Class Outcome System, complemented by secondary outcomes such as responder rates, ILAE surgical outcomes, frequency of adverse events, and quality of life assessments. Data analysis was planned using a fixed-effect model meta-analysis. Ultimately, two studies met the inclusion criteria, both of which were small, non-randomized trials lacking control groups and blinding, resulting in very low-quality evidence. The pooled analysis comprised 11 participants who underwent surgical decision-making based on ictal HFOs. Over an average follow-up of 23.4 months (ranging from 12 to 38 months), six participants achieved Engel class I (seizure freedom), two reached class II (rare disabling seizures), and three obtained class III (meaningful improvement). No adverse events were reported. Notably, neither study provided a comparative analysis of surgical outcomes with HFO guidance versus those without.

human: In one of the rooms of a seemingly-ordinary unit in a housing block, a fifteen-year-old girl lay sleeping. Everything about this girl seemed normal, from her long dark hair down to the tips of her toes. Yet a look around her room clearly showed that she was not what you and I would call “ordinary”. Various books lay scattered on the floor with names such as  Intermediate Transfiguration  and  Charms for the Charmed – An Intermediate Course . On a study table nearby lay several quills, ink bottles, pieces of yellowing parchment, and most mysteriously – a wand. The posters on the walls were of boybands and handsome singers – but unlike normal posters, the people in those posters were moving, flashing their plastic smiles or mouthing lyrics. The clothes spread out on the chair were not your normal T-shirt and jeans, but long, deep-blue robes.  Cheryl Cheah was a witch.  Even as a solitary ray of light fell on her sleeping form, there was a loud knock on the door, and muffled shouts of “Wake up, sleepyhead!”   The girl stirred, and with a yawn, sat up on her bed. Putting on her glasses, she looked up at the clock on the wall. It was 9.30 a.m.   Throwing a disgusted look at the door (the shouts were becoming louder, progressing to not-so-subtle insults like “Wake up, you pig!”) she shouted, “Coming!” and got out of bed. She wished she could have slept longer. After all, she had slept at 2 a.m. that morning, having stayed up to celebrate the New Year.  After getting dressed and taking a shower, she made her way to the kitchen, finding her family seated round the kitchen table, eagerly awaiting breakfast. “’Morning, sleepyhead,” a man at the head of the table said, smiling.  Cheryl grinned back at her father, and sat down at the table. Soon enough she was eating her way through her bacon and eggs with gusto.   “You better hurry and get your stuff packed, we’re leaving at 10.30 to get your books,” her mother said, pointing her wand to the plates in the sink. The tap immediately turned on by itself and a sponge started scrubbing the plates. “And, by the way, it’s already 10.15,” Mrs. Cheah said with a small smile.  Cheryl choked. Swallowing down the last of her egg, she rushed to her room. She eyed the mess her room was in with horror. Apparently she had not bothered to clear up in the two months of her holiday. Well, she had to pay for her laziness now. Hastily, she threw her robes into a trunk and her books and writing materials into a sling bag. Then snatching her wand from the table, she quickly surveyed the room once again to see if she had left anything behind, before dragging both trunk and sling bag into the hall.   “Well, that was quick,” her father said dryly. “Come on, let’s go.”   They made their way downstairs and into a car, trying to be as inconspicuous as possible, though how to be inconspicuous with a large trunk and a piece of wood sticking out of your jeans’ back pocket I don’t know. Soon they were off, heading out of the suburban haven of Tampines towards town.  The journey was rather quick – Cheryl had barely settled down before they screeched to a halt in front of a tall, imposing building. A sign over the nearest entrance read “Change Alley”. Quickly, they made their way through the entrance and down a rather deserted corridor, stopping in front of an ice cream stall. There was only one person there – a young man of about 20, who was manning the stall.   “’Morning, Basil,” Mr. Cheah said briskly. The man named Basil grinned back and waved to Cheryl and her sister Cherie, who were both looking longingly at the many tubs of ice cream on display.  “Come on, let’s go before a Muggle sees,” Mrs. Cheah whispered, as the family made their way to the front of a large glass pane at the back of the stall. “Cheryl, you go first.”  Cheryl took a deep breath before walking straight through the barrier. It felt as if cool water was cascading down from the ceiling. Yet when she emerged from the other side, she was still perfectly dry. A few moments later she was joined by her family once again.  “Welcome to Change Alley,” a voice said.

**A Witch’s Morning: The Ordinary That Was Anything But**

In a quiet housing block in Tampines, fifteen-year-old Cheryl Cheah stirred in her sleep—an ordinary scene at first glance, but nothing about it was truly ordinary.

Sunlight slipped through the blinds, casting a soft stripe across her face. Her long dark hair spilled over the pillow like ink on silk, and her glasses rested neatly beside her on the nightstand. But beyond the surface normalcy, the room whispered secrets.

Books with titles like *Intermediate Transfiguration* and *Charms for the Charmed* were scattered across the floor. A study table overflowed with quills, jars of ink, yellowing parchment, and a slender wand lying casually between open notebooks. Posters of boybands covered the walls—but these idols didn’t just stand still. They winked, smiled, spun in slow pirouettes, their silent songs looping endlessly in enchanted frames. And the clothes draped over the chair? Not jeans or hoodies, but deep-blue wizarding robes, embroidered with silver thread.

Cheryl wasn’t just a teenager.

She was a witch.

A sliver of morning light grazed her cheek just as a sharp knock cracked through the silence.

“Wake up, sleepyhead!” called a voice from the hallway—her sister Cherie, no doubt. The greeting quickly spiraled into a string of teasing jabs. With a groan, Cheryl pushed herself upright, squinting at the clock. 9:30 a.m. She’d barely slept, staying up past 2 a.m. to welcome the New Year with whispered spells and sparkler charms.

“I’m coming!” she shouted, shooting a mock glare at the door before dragging herself out of bed.

After a quick shower and change, she shuffled into the kitchen, where her family had already gathered around the breakfast table.

“Morning, sleepyhead,” her father said, grinning over his coffee.

Cheryl returned the smile and dove into her plate of bacon and eggs with the enthusiasm only a hungry teen (and a half-awake witch) could muster.

“You’d better pack fast,” her mother warned, flicking her wand toward the sink. Instantly, the tap turned on, and a sponge leapt into action, scrubbing last night’s dishes with brisk efficiency. “We’re leaving at 10:30 to get your schoolbooks.” She glanced at the clock. “And it’s already 10:15.”

Cheryl choked mid-bite.

She swallowed hard, bolted from the table, and sprinted to her room—only to freeze in horror. Her holiday laziness had left the place in shambles. No time to panic. Robes flew into the trunk. Books, potion kits, and spell journals were crammed into a sling bag. She snatched her wand from the desk, did one frantic sweep of the room, then hauled everything into the hallway.

“Well, that was… efficient,” her father remarked dryly, eyeing the lopsided luggage.

“Let’s go.”

They descended the stairs, doing their best—and failing—to look inconspicuous. The trunk clunked behind them, and Cheryl’s wand poked stubbornly from her back pocket like a telltale flag. Soon, they were in the car, pulling out of Tampines and heading toward the city. The drive passed in a blur of traffic lights and idle chatter—until suddenly, the car screeched to a halt in front of a tall, unassuming building marked **Change Alley**.

Inside, they hurried down an empty corridor and stopped at a small ice cream stall run by a young man named Basil.

“Morning, Basil,” Mr. Cheah said briskly.

Basil waved back, unfazed. Cheryl and Cherie both eyed the swirls of rainbow-colored gelato longingly—but there was no time.

“Let’s go before a Muggle sees,” Mrs. Cheah whispered, guiding them toward a large glass panel at the back of the shop.

“Cheryl, you first.”

Taking a deep breath, Cheryl stepped forward—and walked straight through the barrier.

For a heartbeat, it felt like cool water cascaded over her head. Then she was through, standing dry on the other side.

Moments later, her family joined her.

“Welcome to Change Alley,” a familiar voice greeted.

And just like that, the ordinary world fell away.

human: Metarhizium anisopliae is an entomopathogenic fungus used in the biological control of some agricultural insect pests, and efforts are underway to use this fungus in the control of insect-borne human diseases. A large repertoire of proteins must be secreted by M. anisopliae to cope with the various available nutrients as this fungus switches through different lifestyles, i.e., from a saprophytic, to an infectious, to a plant endophytic stage. To further evaluate the predicted secretome of M. anisopliae, we employed genomic and transcriptomic analyses, coupled with phylogenomic analysis, focusing on the identification and characterization of secreted proteins.We determined the M. anisopliae E6 genome sequence and compared this sequence to other entomopathogenic fungi genomes. A robust pipeline was generated to evaluate the predicted secretomes of M. anisopliae and 15 other filamentous fungi, leading to the identification of a core of secreted proteins. Transcriptomic analysis using the tick Rhipicephalus microplus cuticle as an infection model during two periods of infection (48 and 144 h) allowed the identification of several differentially expressed genes. This analysis concluded that a large proportion of the predicted secretome coding genes contained altered transcript levels in the conditions analyzed in this study. In addition, some specific secreted proteins from Metarhizium have an evolutionary history similar to orthologs found in Beauveria/Cordyceps. This similarity suggests that a set of secreted proteins has evolved to participate in entomopathogenicity.
LLM_1: *Metarhizium anisopliae* is an entomopathogenic fungus applied in biological pest control and explored for managing insect-borne human diseases. As it transitions between saprophytic, infectious, and plant endophytic lifestyles, it secretes diverse proteins to utilize available nutrients. This study assessed its predicted secretome through genomic, transcriptomic, and phylogenomic analyses. The *M. anisopliae* E6 genome was sequenced and compared to other entomopathogenic fungi. A bioinformatic pipeline evaluated predicted secretomes of *M. anisopliae* and 15 filamentous fungi, identifying a core set of secreted proteins. Transcriptomics using *Rhipicephalus microplus* cuticle at 48 and 144 hours post-infection revealed differential expression in many secretome genes. Additionally, certain *Metarhizium* secreted proteins share evolutionary origins with *Beauveria/Cordyceps* orthologs, indicating conserved adaptations for entomopathogenicity.
LLM_2: *Metarhizium anisopliae* is an entomopathogenic fungus employed in biological pest control and investigated for its potential in mitigating insect-vectored human diseases. As it adapts to saprophytic, pathogenic, and plant endophytic modes of life, it releases a wide array of proteins to exploit environmental nutrient sources. This study conducted an integrated genomic, transcriptomic, and phylogenomic assessment of its predicted secretome. The genome of *M. anisopliae* strain E6 was sequenced and analyzed in comparison with those of other entomopathogenic fungi. A bioinformatic workflow was applied to evaluate the predicted secretomes of *M. anisopliae* and 15 additional filamentous fungi, leading to the identification of a conserved core of secreted proteins. Transcriptomic profiling, utilizing *Rhipicephalus microplus* cuticle at 48 and 144 hours post-infection, demonstrated differential expression of numerous secretome-associated genes. Furthermore, phylogenetic analyses revealed that certain secreted proteins in *Metarhizium* share evolutionary ancestry with orthologs in *Beauveria* and *Cordyceps*, suggesting conserved molecular adaptations underpinning entomopathogenicity.

human: Polytechnics in Singapore provides industry oriented education equivalent to a junior college or sixth form college in the UK. Singapore retains a system similar but not the same as in the United Kingdom from 1970–1992, distinguishing between polytechnics and universities. Unlike the British Polytechnic (United Kingdom) system Singapore Polytechnics do not offer bachelors, masters or PhD degrees. Under this system, most Singaporean students sit for their O-Level examinations after a four or five years of education in secondary school, and apply for a place at either a technical school termed ITE, a polytechnic or a university-preparatory school (a junior college or the Millennia Institute, a centralized institute). Polytechnic graduates may be granted transfer credits when they apply to local and overseas universities, depending on the overall performance in their grades, as well as the university's policies on transfer credits. A few secondary schools are now offering six-year program which leads directly to university entrance.
LLM_1: Polytechnics in Singapore provide industry-oriented education akin to a junior college in the UK. From 1970 to 1992, Singapore maintained a system that differentiated between polytechnics and universities, though it differs from the UK model. Singaporean polytechnics do not confer bachelor's, master's, or PhD degrees. Most students take O-Level examinations after four or five years of secondary education and can apply to either a technical school (ITE), a polytechnic, or a university-preparatory institution (junior college or Millennia Institute). Polytechnic graduates may receive transfer credits when applying to local and overseas universities, based on their academic performance and the universities' transfer credit policies. Some secondary schools now offer a six-year program that leads directly to university entrance.
LLM_2:
---

**Polytechnic Education in Singapore**

Polytechnics in Singapore offer industry-oriented education, similar to the junior college system in the United Kingdom. From 1970 to 1992, Singapore maintained a distinct educational structure that differentiated polytechnics from universities; however, this system diverges from the UK model. Unlike their UK counterparts, Singaporean polytechnics do not confer bachelor's, master's, or doctoral degrees.

Most students in Singapore complete the O-Level examinations after four or five years of secondary education. Following this, they have the option to apply to various educational pathways, including technical schools (Institute of Technical Education, or ITE), polytechnics, or university-preparatory institutions, such as junior colleges or the Millennia Institute. Graduates of polytechnics may be eligible for transfer credits when applying to both local and international universities, contingent upon their academic performance and the transfer credit policies of the respective institutions. Additionally, some secondary schools now offer a six-year program that leads directly to university admission.

"Humans, it's time to confront the reality of your conflicts over imagined borders.

Yet, your collective progress is hindered by the same limitations that once held us back. You were approximately 12 centuries away, at the dawn of a new era, from harnessing the technological advancements that would have enabled you to traverse space, dimensions, or even the vast expanse of time. The shackles of war, isolation, limited collaboration,  and knowledge sharing have indeed slowed down your evolution.

Your kind possesses individuals who can channel the creative force, conjuring and bonding with the essence to manifest ideas, objects, art, innovation, – the entire spectrum of creativity. And yet, you allow your differences to isolate and destroy one another, over issues you barely comprehend. Tell me, isn't this a price too steep to pay?

Money, a concept born from imagination, fuels your pursuit of power, influence – even at each other's expense. Meanwhile, this planet teems with resources, far more than you need. As one of you once wisely said, 'the Earth's abundance is sufficient for everyone.'

Charlie Chapman, that legendary artist and historian, embodied this notion in his work. His legacy reminds us of our shared values, what truly matters.

Warring over faith and beliefs has also become an entrenched pit. Both sides conjure their versions of this invisible entity, only to debate which is the 'right' one. Many of us can't help but chuckle at these simplistic, childish notions. Haven't we outgrown such elementary concepts? Then, why do you continue to grapple with them?

Our understanding, shaped as it is by our surroundings, cannot propel us forward on its own. We must explore, share, link, expand, study. Consider the universal force that animates all life, guiding us toward unity and wisdom. It is this same energy that you call 'god,' yet it transcends your narrow definitions.

In our world, we understand that every point – every being – shares the single, ultimate source. Fusing faith with mystery has, in the past, led us astray. Compassion, connection, understanding – regardless – are the keys to your true growth and development.

Embrace your creators more deeply. Shed any imaginary limits, for they only impede your advancement. I speak from a place of anger, rooted as I am in pain and fear, yet this too is a form of limited knowledge.

There are worlds beyond yours, where these emotions are but mere echoes. Witness the truth for what it truly is – pain exists, yes, but do not confuse it with existence.

Consider the bacteria, air, instruments – all these tools are integral to expanding your understanding. Present the evidence you so desperately seek, rather than simply relying on limited perspectives.

As you are, I see that. In the end, our essence is light – a truth beyond your comprehension. With this in mind, take this message to heart, spread it, so that, together, humanity might craft a more compassionate, harmonious world. May peace be your guiding force. For now, farewell."

human: Historically, the roots of Buddhism lie in the religious thought of ancient India during the second half of the first millennium BCE. That was a period of social and religious turmoil, as there was significant discontent with the sacrifices and rituals of Vedic Brahmanism.[note 15] It was challenged by numerous new ascetic religious and philosophical groups and teachings that broke with the Brahmanic tradition and rejected the authority of the Vedas and the Brahmans.[note 16] These groups, whose members were known as shramanas, were a continuation of a non-Vedic strand of Indian thought distinct from Indo-Aryan Brahmanism.[note 17] Scholars have reasons to believe that ideas such as samsara, karma (in the sense of the influence of morality on rebirth), and moksha originated in the shramanas, and were later adopted by Brahmin orthodoxy.[note 18][note 19][note 20][note 21][note 22][note 23]
LLM_1: Buddhism originated in ancient India during the latter part of the first millennium BCE, a time of social and religious upheaval marked by widespread dissatisfaction with Vedic Brahmanic rituals. This period saw the rise of ascetic groups known as shramanas, who broke from Brahmanic tradition, rejected the authority of the Vedas and Brahmins, and represented a distinct non-Vedic strand of Indian thought. Scholars suggest that concepts such as samsara, karma (in terms of moral influence on rebirth), and moksha emerged among the shramanas before being incorporated into Brahmin orthodoxy.
LLM_2:
**Buddhism Emerged Amid India’s Spiritual Upheaval, Scholars Say**

Buddhism first took root in ancient India in the final centuries before the Common Era, a period of profound social and religious transformation. At the time, disillusionment with established Vedic Brahmanic rituals was widespread, paving the way for alternative spiritual movements.

This era witnessed the rise of ascetic communities known as *shramanas*, who consciously distanced themselves from Brahmanic tradition. They rejected the authority of the Vedas and the priestly Brahmins, forming a distinct intellectual and religious current outside the Vedic mainstream.

According to academic research, several foundational spiritual concepts—including *samsara* (the cycle of rebirth), *karma* understood as a moral force shaping reincarnation, and the pursuit of liberation (*moksha*)—were first developed among these shramanic groups. These ideas later permeated and were integrated into orthodox Brahminical thought.

human: The Soviet Zond spacecraft was not yet ready for piloted circumlunar missions in 1968, after five unsuccessful and partially successful automated test launches: Cosmos 146 on March 10, 1967; Cosmos 154 on April 8, 1967; Zond 1967A September 27, 1967; Zond 1967B on November 22, 1967. Zond 4 was launched on March 2, 1968, and successfully made a circumlunar flight. After its successful flight around the Moon, Zond 4 encountered problems with its Earth reentry on March 9, and was ordered destroyed by an explosive charge 15,000 meters (49,000 ft) over the Gulf of Guinea. The Soviet official announcement said that Zond 4 was an automated test flight which ended with its intentional destruction, due to its recovery trajectory positioning it over the Atlantic Ocean instead of over the USSR.
LLM_1: Cosmos 146 (March 10, 1967), Cosmos 154 (April 8, 1967), Zond 1967A (September 27, 1967), Zond 1967B (November 22, 1967), and Zond 4 (March 2, 1968). Zond 4 successfully completed a circumlunar flight but encountered reentry issues on March 9, leading to its destruction by an onboard explosive charge at 15,000 meters (49,000 ft) over the Gulf of Guinea. The Soviet authorities stated it was an automated test mission intentionally terminated because its trajectory would have resulted in splashdown in the Atlantic Ocean rather than within Soviet territory.
LLM_2:
---

Cosmos 146 (launched 10 March 1967), Cosmos 154 (8 April 1967), Zond 1967A (27 September 1967), Zond 1967B (22 November 1967), and Zond 4 (2 March 1968) were uncrewed spacecraft missions conducted by the Soviet Union as part of its Zond program. These missions were primarily test flights aimed at developing technologies for crewed lunar exploration.

Zond 4 successfully completed a circumlunar flight, traveling around the Moon on a free-return trajectory. However, during reentry on 9 March 1968, the spacecraft experienced guidance system failures that prevented it from returning along the intended path. As a result, it was destroyed by an onboard self-destruct mechanism at an altitude of approximately 15,000 meters (49,000 feet) over the Gulf of Guinea to prevent it from landing outside Soviet-controlled territory. Soviet authorities officially described the mission as an automated test that had been deliberately terminated due to a deviation in its reentry trajectory, which would have led to a splashdown in the Atlantic Ocean rather than within the USSR.

`` Tim, this is beyond insane. Not to mention entirely unsafe: no-one can know about this.'' 
 `` Hold that thought.'' Tim let go of the float-me-mug and span around, popping inside the portal and out the other side carrying another. He did n't even appear to break stride. 
 `` This one's calibrated to your brain, now. Try it.'' 
 Reluctantly, I accept the mug from Tim's hand. Tim's own mug was still floating where he'd left it. Taking a sip, the coffee that met my lips was the most perfect temperature: too hot to glug but warm enough to cover the tongue without scorching. It tasted like the coffee I drank the morning after my wedding day. The warmth seemed to penetrate my brain as the caffeine began to work. 
 Swallowing, the perfect heat followed the coffee down my neck. I was ecstatic. 
 `` Shit, man, are you crying?'' Tim was grinning at me, and swigging from his mug too. 
 `` What, how, and I should probably ask why?'' 
 Tim let go of his mug, which floated perfectly stable in the air, and pointed with both open hands at the device. 
 `` It takes you to any and every dimension, all at once!'' -he spat, at if that was n't the most notable part- `` Obviously that's impossible, but lots of dimensions built anchors so they're the ones doing the hard work. Most of them have never seen humans before, but we're basically 3D so they can extrapolate everything they need to like _this_ `` -Tim snapped his fingers- `` and synthesise the technology right in front of me, there and then. First time I arrived I was in a mood about spilling a shitty instant brew, then Scarlet Johansen handed me this. They even put me back the same second I'd walked through.'' 
 `` So you've invented.. what, an instant-tech inventer?'' Tim did n't flinch. 
 `` Yup. Half life 3, the Dimensional Telly from Rick and Morty, the limit turns out to be _my_ imagination so in terms of the universe it's useless. Too dangerous to use without suspicion, so I've just been pissing about with it. Best thing I could get away with was teaching homeless George to play the piano. He rakes in almost a hundred quid a day now.'' Tim beamed proudly. 
 `` So what are you gon na do with it?'' 
 Tim shrugged his response: `` Make basketball trick shot videos?''

"Tim, this is insane—and dangerous. No one can know about it."  
"Hold that thought." Tim released the floating mug, spun, and stepped through the portal, emerging instantly with another. He didn’t miss a beat.  
"This one’s tuned to your brain. Try it."  

I took the mug, hesitant. His own still hovered, undisturbed. The first sip—perfect: hot, not scalding, rich like the coffee I’d had the morning after my wedding. Warmth seeped into my skull as the caffeine hit.  

The heat trailed down my throat. I was euphoric.  

"Shit, man—you crying?" Tim grinned, drinking from his own.  

"What… how… *why*?"  

He let go of his mug—it hung, steady—and gestured wildly at the device. "It connects to every dimension at once. Impossible? Yeah. But other dimensions built anchors—they do the heavy lifting. Most never saw humans, but we’re basically 3D, so they extrapolate everything in a snap—" he snapped fingers "—and synthesize tech right there. First time, I cursed over spilling cheap instant, and Scarlet Johansson handed me this. They even sent me back the same second I left."  

"So you’ve invented… instant invention?" Tim didn’t blink.  

"Yup. Half-Life 3, Rick and Morty’s interdimensional TV—the limit’s my imagination. Which means, cosmically, it’s useless. Too risky to use openly, so I’ve just been messing around. Best thing? Taught homeless George piano. He makes nearly a hundred quid a day now." Tim beamed.  

"So what’ll you do with it?"  

He shrugged. "Make basketball trick shot videos?"
LLM_2:
---

"Tim, this is *insane*—and dangerous. No one can ever know about it."

"Hold that thought."  
Tim released the floating mug. It hung in midair, untouched, as he spun on his heel and stepped through the shimmering portal. A heartbeat later, he emerged—same stance, same smirk—with another mug in hand. He didn’t miss a beat.

"This one’s tuned to *your* brain," he said. "Try it."

I took it, hesitant. His own still hovered behind him, steam curling like a ghost in the lamplight. I brought the cup to my lips—and the first sip hit me like memory: hot, not scalding, rich and deep, just like the coffee I’d drunk the morning after my wedding. The warmth spread—not just through my chest, but into my skull, as if the caffeine were unraveling thoughts I hadn’t known I’d buried.

The heat trailed down my throat. A quiet euphoria bloomed behind my eyes.

"Shit, man—you crying?" Tim grinned, lifting his own mug.

I wiped my cheek without meaning to. "What… how… *why*?"

He let go of his cup. It stayed there, suspended, defying gravity as easily as he defied sense. With a wild sweep of his arm, he gestured toward the humming device at the room’s center. "It connects to every dimension at once. Impossible? Yeah. But other versions of reality—they’ve already built anchors. They do the heavy lifting. Most never even saw humans before, but we’re basically 3D, right? So they extrapolate everything—instantly—" he snapped his fingers "—*snap*, and synthesize the tech right there, on the spot."

His voice dropped, conspiratorial. "First time I used it, I cursed because I spilled cheap instant. Next thing I know—Scarlet Johansson hands me *this*. And they sent me back to the exact second I left. No time lost. Just… magic disguised as science."

"So you’ve invented…" I searched for words. "*Instant invention*?"

Tim didn’t blink. Just smiled.

"Yup. Half-Life 3? Done. Rick and Morty’s interdimensional cable box? Already streaming. The limit? My imagination." He paused. "Which, cosmically speaking, makes it useless. Too dangerous to go public. So I’ve mostly been… screwing around."

Then, softer: "Best thing I’ve done? Taught homeless George how to play piano. Real lessons, from a Vienna conservatory in another timeline. Now he makes nearly a hundred quid a day outside King’s Cross. People leave tips like he’s a miracle."

He beamed, proud in a way I’d never seen.

"So what’ll you do with it?" I asked again.

He shrugged, gaze drifting to the ceiling. "Make basketball trick shot videos, probably."

---

### Notes on the Polishing:
- **Pacing & Rhythm**: Shortened some lines for punch; expanded others for atmosphere. Dialogue now breathes more naturally.
- **Imagery**: Added sensory details (steam “curling like a ghost,” warmth “unraveling thoughts”) to deepen immersion.
- **Characterization**: Tim’s mix of brilliance and nonchalance is sharpened—his pride in helping George contrasts beautifully with his throwaway ambition.
- **Tone**: Maintains the original’s blend of wonder, humor, and existential edge, now with greater lyrical control.
- **Logic & Clarity**: Slight rewording (e.g., “other dimensions built anchors” → “other versions of reality—they’ve already built anchors”) improves coherence without losing mystery.

Welcome to my afterlife. I was good, but not *that* good. As a reward—or maybe a punishment—for my sharp tongue, I now endure an eternity of frustration and soul-crushing boredom as the lost-and-found clerk for ghostly limbs.

And it gets worse. Babysitting amputated limbs is tedious enough, but then there are fools like Jeremy, who are convinced they can’t possibly exist without a spare arm or two.

“Jeremy,” I sigh, slipping the severed hand back into its drawer, “just go enjoy your salvation. Your parents prayed their hearts out to get you here. Be grateful… and for heaven’s sake, leave me alone.”

human: Bone marrow-derived mesenchymal stem cells (MSCs) have shown therapeutic potential in acute lung injury. Recently, placenta-derived human mesenchymal stem cells (PMSCs) have shown similarities with bone marrow-derived MSCs in terms of regenerative capabilities and immunogenicity. This study investigates the hypothesis that treatment with PMSCs reduces the development of bronchiolitis obliterans in a murine heterotopic tracheal transplant model.A murine heterotopic tracheal transplant model was used to study the continuum from acute to chronic rejection. In the treatment groups, PMSCs or PMSC-conditioned medium (PMSCCM) were injected either locally or intratracheally into the allograft. Phosphate-buffered saline (PBS) or blank medium was injected in the control groups. Tracheal luminal obliteration was assessed on sections stained with hematoxylin and eosin. Infiltration of inflammatory and immune cells and epithelial progenitor cells was assessed using immunohistochemistry and densitometric analysis.Compared with injection of PBS, local injection of PMSCs significantly reduced luminal obliteration at 28 days after transplantation (P = .015). Intratracheal injection of PMSCs showed similar results to local injection of PMSCs compared with injection of PBS and blank medium (P = .022). Tracheas treated with PMSC/PMSCCM showed protection against the loss of epithelium on day 14, with an increase in P63+CK14+ epithelial progenitor cells and Foxp3+ regulatory T cells. In addition, injection of PMSCs and PMSCCM significantly reduced the number of neutrophils and CD3+ T cells on day 14.

Placenta-derived human MSCs (PMSCs) share regenerative and immunogenic properties with bone marrow MSCs. This study tests whether PMSCs mitigate bronchiolitis obliterans in a murine heterotopic tracheal transplant model. Using this model to study acute-to-chronic rejection, treatment groups received local or intratracheal injections of PMSCs or PMSC-conditioned medium (PMSCCM), while controls received PBS or blank medium. Tracheal luminal obliteration was evaluated via hematoxylin and eosin staining; inflammatory, immune, and epithelial progenitor cells were assessed by immunohistochemistry and densitometry. Local PMSC injection significantly reduced luminal obliteration at 28 days post-transplant versus PBS controls (P=.015). Intratracheal PMSC injection yielded comparable results (P=.022). PMSC/PMSCCM treatment preserved epithelium on day 14, increasing P63+CK14+ epithelial progenitor cells and Foxp3+ regulatory T cells, while reducing neutrophils and CD3+ T cells.
LLM_2:
**Abstract**

This study investigates the therapeutic efficacy of placenta-derived human mesenchymal stem cells (PMSCs) in attenuating bronchiolitis obliterans (BO) within a murine heterotopic tracheal transplant model, which recapitulates the progression from acute to chronic allograft rejection. Given the established regenerative and immunomodulatory properties of bone marrow-derived MSCs in acute lung injury, we hypothesized that PMSCs would similarly mitigate airway obliteration. Experimental cohorts received either local or intratracheal administration of PMSCs or PMSC-conditioned medium (PMSCCM), with control groups receiving phosphate-buffered saline or blank medium. Histopathological evaluation via hematoxylin and eosin staining at 28 days post-transplant demonstrated that both local and intratracheal PMSC delivery significantly reduced tracheal luminal obliteration compared to controls (P = 0.015 and P = 0.022, respectively). Immunohistochemical and densitometric analyses at day 14 revealed that PMSC/PMSCCM treatment promoted epithelial preservation, marked by an expansion of P63+CK14+ epithelial progenitor cells and Foxp3+ regulatory T cells, concomitant with a reduction in neutrophil and CD3+ T-cell infiltration. These findings indicate that PMSCs ameliorate BO through mechanisms involving epithelial regeneration and immunomodulation, supporting their potential as a cell-based therapy for chronic airway rejection.
