She said the coalition had made changes to the system and had further plans for the next Parliament.
Labour's Yvette Cooper said the Tory pledge from 2010 was in "tatters" but did not identify a target herself.
They were taking part in a Daily Politics debate on BBC Two.
Lib Dem Norman Baker said the target of tens of thousands was "non-deliverable", while UKIP's Steve Woolfe said his party was in favour of a "fair, ethical, non-discriminatory" system.
Plaid Cymru's Simon Thomas, meanwhile, said his party would not allow immigrants to be "scapegoated".
The Conservatives said at the last election that they wanted to reduce net migration - the difference between the numbers of people moving to live in the UK and the numbers of people leaving - to the "tens of thousands" by May 2015.
But figures earlier this year showed annual net migration had risen to 298,000.
Ms May said: "We've accepted that we have failed to meet that particular target."
Asked why people should trust her party this time, she said: "We've actually shown that we have made some changes to the immigration system.
"And crucially we have set out a credible plan for what we would do for the future, in terms of tightening up, not just on EU immigration but also on people from outside the EU."
Ms Cooper, quizzed about her party's reluctance to identify a target, said Labour was proposing "practical things we believe should change".
She said she wanted to see the net migration figure "come down".
And she said part of the problem was agencies and employers "driving low-skilled migration" to undercut local pay.
Mr Baker said his party had a strong record in government. Asked why the Lib Dems had not supported the Conservative target, he said: "You can't have a target for the number of days it's going to rain each year. It's a non-deliverable target."
But he said the most recent migration figure was "probably too much".
UKIP's Mr Woolfe said leaving the European Union was the only way to reduce the figure.
He said: "It's absolutely clear - Plaid Cymru and their leader Leanne Wood said in the debates between the leaders - that you cannot reduce migration in this country, net or otherwise, unless you are outside of the European Union."
His party wants immigration to return to "normal" levels, leader Nigel Farage has said.
Mr Thomas, meanwhile, said the Welsh economy needed migrants.
He added: "We want the voice of Wales to be heard."
Ms May also said during the debate that currently one person was on a Terrorism Prevention and Investigation Measure, or TPim.
The home secretary can consider imposing a TPim if MI5 "reasonably believes" someone is involved in terrorism-related activities.
Ms Cooper questioned why more people were not subject to the orders, given the number of Britons known to have taken part in the conflict in Syria.
"Despite all the people coming back from Syria and despite all the concerns that have been raised about terror suspects and so on, they've only got one person under a TPim and that is because they weakened the powers and removed the relocation powers," she said.
Ms May said it was up to the security services to identify people who should be subject to TPims and denied they had not identified those who had travelled to Syria.
"We do know people coming back," she said.
LLM_1:
The coalition has made changes to the immigration system and has further plans for the next Parliament. Labour's Yvette Cooper criticized the Conservative pledge from 2010 as being in "tatters" but did not specify a target. During a Daily Politics debate on BBC Two, Lib Dem Norman Baker called the target of tens of thousands "non-deliverable," while UKIP's Steve Woolfe advocated for a "fair, ethical, non-discriminatory" system. Plaid Cymru's Simon Thomas stated his party would not allow immigrants to be "scapegoated."

The Conservatives aimed to reduce net migration—the difference between arrivals and departures—to the "tens of thousands" by May 2015, but recent figures indicated it had risen to 298,000. Ms. May acknowledged the failure to meet this target and emphasized that changes had been made to the immigration system. She presented a credible future plan to tighten immigration for both EU and non-EU arrivals.

Ms. Cooper, when asked about Labour's target, indicated the party was proposing practical changes to reduce net migration, citing concerns over agencies driving low-skilled migration that undercuts local wages. Mr. Baker defended the Lib Dems' record in government and criticized the Conservative target as unrealistic, acknowledging that current migration levels were "probably too much."

UKIP's Mr. Woolfe asserted that leaving the EU was essential to lowering migration figures, stating that Plaid Cymru's leaders acknowledged this in debates. His party seeks to return immigration to "normal" levels, as stated by leader Nigel Farage. Mr. Thomas emphasized the necessity of migrants for the Welsh economy and the importance of representing Wales.

During the debate, Ms. May noted that only one person is currently subject to a Terrorism Prevention and Investigation Measure (TPim). She explained that the home secretary can impose a TPim based on MI5’s assessment of terrorism involvement. Ms. Cooper questioned the low number of TPims, given the return of Britons from Syria, arguing that weakened powers have contributed to this issue. Ms. May maintained that it is the responsibility of security services to identify individuals for TPims and asserted that they are aware of those returning from Syria.

human: Well, the colonoscopy went well...I think...the nurse said that I would be in a twilight state for the procedure.  There was not a semi-conscious moment for me.  One minute I'm asking which monitor I should watch and the next I'm waking in recovery to the sound of a machine beeping out my pulse.  On the drive home, I described things I had seen during the procedure to my wife of which I now have no recollection.  I barely remember telling her anything.  Lack of control over thought and speech is downright frightening when it happens (that is, once one regains control and has had a chance to reflect upon it.)  IF I could think right now, I would be attempting to discuss the ages-old philosophical problem of the relationship between the mind and body.  My views lean toward the materialistic with an acknowledgement towards emergent consciousness.  The Wikipedia has a decent introductory  urlLink article  on the issue.  Thinking about these things leads to questions on  urlLink epistemology ,  urlLink morality , and  urlLink free will .  All subjects I love to discuss, especially with those that have it all down pat.  But now, I just need to lie down.  Oh, and no polyps, no tumors, just a simple treatable humble internal condition with a blood vessel.
LLM_1:
I underwent a colonoscropy, which was a blur. I recall asking the nurse which monitors to watch, then waking up in the recovery room to a beeper tracking my heartbeat. On our drive back, my husband asked me to describe what I'd seen, yet I couldn't recall a thing. This lack of memory and control is unsettling, even after reflecting on it. 

The procedure revealed a treatble condition involving a single blood vessels, with no signs of polyp or tumor. As I recover, philosophical ideas on mind-body dualism resurface. My perspective leans towards a materialist view, acknowledging emergant consciousness.

This line of thinking sparks questions about epistomology, morality, free-will, all of interest to me, particularly when engaging with experts. However, for now I need rest. A link to an introductory article on this topic can be found on Wikipedia. These subjects will have to wait until I regain my energy. Time to take it easy.
LLM_2:
**A Personal Journey: Reflections on a Colonoscopy**

As I navigated the haze of a recent colonosopy, memories were hazy, like a dream I was struggling to recall. One of my first recollections was asking a nurse for clarification on the monitors beeping away, only to wake up to my own heartbeat being tracked in recovery. Our drive home was an opportunity for my partner to inquire about my experience, unfortunately, I drew a complete blank.

Reflecting on that experience has left me with an unsettling sense of powerlessness, despite the fact that I've had time to process it all. But what really caught my attention was the outcome of that procedure. It revealed an issue that can indeed be treated – a condition affecting a solitary blood vessel – with a clean bill of health regarding polyps or tumors.

As my recovery progresses, age-old philosophical conundrums resurfaced, specifically those related to mind and body dualisms. With a leaning towards materialism and the emergence of consciousness, these questions have always fascinated me. When engaging in discussions with subject matter experts, epistemology and morality become particularly intriguing topics. Moreover, questions surrounding free will also capture my imagination.

However, as I focus on my convalescence, it's essential to prioritize rest over intellectual pursuits. For those interested in exploring these ideas further, a helpful introduction can found [here](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mind%E2%B0body_problem) on wikipedia. Perhaps, after I regroup my energies, we can delve deeper into these subjects. Until then, taking it slow is the order of business.

human: We have investigated the effects of BRCA1 over-expression and knockdown on 5F-203-induced gene expression and cytotoxicity in human breast cancer cells. 5F-203 is a chemotherapeutic prodrug that both induces a p450 enzyme, CYP1A1, and is metabolically activated by CYP1A1.We used several molecular biological techniques to confirm our findings. BRCA1 regulates sensitivity to 5F-203 by regulating the expression of CYP1A1 mRNA and its EROD activity. XRE-Luc reporter assays, semi-quantitative RT-PCR, Western blot analysis, EROD activity measurements, gene knockdown and MTT cell survival assays were used for this study.Our results show that the ability of 5F-203 treatments to increase CYP1A1 mRNA level and CYP1A1 enzymatic activity (EROD activity) are affected by BRCA1 protein levels. In addition, the ability of 5F-203 treatments to induce proteins, P53 and P53 target genes such as P21, is significantly decreased in BRCA1 knockdown cells, suggesting that BRCA1-related effects could at least partially explain why BRCA1 knockdown increases resistance to 5F-203-mediated cytotoxicity. We also observed altered expression of the two major transcription factors (AhR and ARNT) that affect CYP1A1 expression when BRCA1 protein levels are altered.
LLM_1: We investigated how BRACA1 affects the response of human-breast cancer-cells to a chemotherapy pro-drug,  203. This pro drug induces the enzyme Cyp1a1 and activates it. Using molecular biology techniques, we found that  BRAC1 controls the sensitivity of these cells to this pro-durg by managing the levels of a key enzyme's mRNA (Cyp 1 a1) and activity, as well as other proteins involved in cell response, such a P 53. Our results indicate that levels BR  ACA  protein impact the effectiveness of this treatment, affecting the proteins' expression involved. Furthermore, altering BR ACA levels changes the activity of key transcription factor involved (AHR and A R N T), that control the gene's expression. These findings suggest that B R ACA plays a crucial role in how these cancer-cell respond to chemotherapy.
LLM_2: Our investigation into the mechanisms governing the responsiveness of breast cancer cells exposed to  the chemotherapeutic prodrug 204 revealed a pivotal role for BRCA1. Specifically, this study aimed to elucidate how  this DNA repair enzyme modulates the cellular response to treatment. Through the application of molecular  biology tools, our findings indicated that BR CA1 orchestrates the susceptibility of cancerous cells by regulating  both the transcript and protein levels associated with the CYP1A1 enzyme, a critical mediator of pro-  drug activation. Notably, alterations in BR C A1 protein expression also impacted the expression of P53, another  key protein involved  in cellular  response. Moreover, modifications in  B  R  C  A  levels  significantly  influenced  transcriptional regulation, specifically through the modulation of AHR  and ARNT, crucial transcription factors governing gene expression in response  to chemotoxic stress. Collectively, these results underscore the critical role of BR AC A in modulating the  effectiveness  of chemotherapy  treatment in breast  cancer  cells.

human:
This paper proposes using reinforcement learning to train a robot for aligning an interferometer. They extend setting to a richer observation and action spaces that are closer to the real-world. To work with continuous action spaces, TD3 algorithm is used. Additional novel components include predicting the actions in the log space to handle the large range of actions, and adding phase noise for domain randomization.

Strengths:
- The experimental evaluation, particularly on the real system, is convincing, and shows that the proposed approach can outperform the baseline, and a human. Further, the method discovers parallel movement, which is interesting.

Weaknesses:
- The section on action rescaling (line 216) was a little confusing — specifically, it wasn't clear how this is related to the exploration noise. It seems like exploration noise is reduced by decaying the standard deviation of the Gaussian noise (line 230).
- It might be helpful to have a discussion of whether the proposed system is specific to the setup considered, or whether it could generalize to other related systems.

Originality: Fair: Incremental work, no significant advance.
Technical Quality: Very Good:  Convincing.
Clarity of Presentation: Good: Minor revision needed to improve organization or clarity.
Impact: 2: Unsure, difficult to assess.
Recommendation: Weak Accept: I recommend accepting the paper, but will not argue for my recommendation if the majority of other reviewers have a different opinion.

Summary of Recommendation: The paper extends prior work to a practical real-world system, and can potentially be used to implement reinforcement learning in other real-world systems.

Issues:
- Clarify how action rescaling is related to exploration noise.
- Discuss how the method may / may not be used in other real-world applications.

Reviewer Expertise: Fair: Some knowledge of the area
LLM_1:
This paper applies reinforcement learning to train a robot for interferometer alignment, extending prior work with richer observation and action spaces that better reflect real-world conditions. The TD3 algorithm is used to handle continuous actions, with novel additions including action prediction in log space to accommodate a wide action range and phase noise injection for domain randomization.

Strengths:
- The experimental evaluation, especially on the real system, is convincing, demonstrating that the approach outperforms both a baseline and a human operator. The discovery of parallel movement is an interesting outcome.

Weaknesses:
- The action rescaling discussion (line 216) is somewhat unclear, particularly its relationship to exploration noise. It appears exploration noise is reduced by decaying the Gaussian noise standard deviation (line 230).
- A discussion on the generalizability of the method to other systems would be beneficial.

Originality: Fair: Incremental.
Technical Quality: Very Good: Convincing.
Clarity of Presentation: Good: Minor revisions needed.
Impact: 2: Unsure.
Recommendation: Weak Accept.

Summary: The paper extends prior work to a practical real-world system, with potential for broader RL applications in similar settings.

Issues:
- Clarify the connection between action rescaling and exploration noise.
- Discuss the method's applicability to other real-world systems.

Reviewer Expertise: Fair.
LLM_2:
This paper extends prior work by applying reinforcement learning to train a robot for interferometer alignment, using richer observation and action spaces that better reflect real-world conditions. The TD3 algorithm is employed for continuous control, with novel contributions including action prediction in log space to accommodate a wide action range and phase noise injection for domain randomization.

**Strengths**  
- The experimental evaluation, particularly on the physical system, is compelling and demonstrates that the proposed approach outperforms both a baseline and a human operator. The discovery of parallel movement as an emergent behavior is an interesting and noteworthy result.

**Weaknesses**  
- The discussion of action rescaling (line 216) is somewhat unclear, especially regarding its relationship to exploration noise. It appears that exploration noise is reduced by decaying the Gaussian noise standard deviation (line 230), but the connection could be elaborated.  
- The paper would benefit from a discussion on the generalizability of the method to other robotic or real-world systems.

**Originality**  
**Fair (Incremental):** The work builds directly on prior research with meaningful but incremental extensions.

**Technical Quality**  
**Very Good (Convincing):** The methodology is sound, and the real-world experiments are well-executed and persuasive.

**Clarity of Presentation**  
**Good (Minor Revisions Needed):** The paper is generally well-written, though certain sections—particularly the action rescaling discussion—require clarification.

**Impact**  
**2 (Unsure):** While the results are promising for interferometer alignment, the broader applicability and impact on the field remain uncertain.

**Recommendation**  
**Weak Accept**

**Overall Assessment**  
This paper successfully extends prior reinforcement learning work to a practical real-world robotic system, demonstrating potential for broader RL applications in similar experimental or industrial settings. The real-system validation is a key strength, though the presentation could be improved in specific areas.

**Suggested Revisions**  
1. Clarify the relationship between action rescaling and exploration noise in the relevant section.  
2. Include a brief discussion on the method’s applicability to other real-world systems or domains.

**Reviewer Expertise**  
Fair

human: A deep-learning-based approach for surgical step recognition is described. It consists of two components - a feature extractor (3D ConvNet) and a time-series model (Conv1D / LSTM/ TSAN). Video data of four different laparoscopic surgeries is used and combined by transfer learning. Furthermore, a self-supervised learning strategy by temporal sequence sorting is introduced. The general idea of combining data of different laparoscopic surgeries due to same / similar steps is reasonable. However, the applied strategy of freezing a feature extractor trained on a single surgery is not clear to me. Please motivate. The idea of unsupervised pre-training via sequence sorting is neat and easy to implement. Please describe your data in more detail. What is the size and dimension of your data? I assume one temporal axis, 2 spatial ones and one channel axis (RGB)? How is the temporal resolution? Please also describe the steps of the Cholecystectomy cases. I would prefer a data section in front of the methods section. The paper is quite hard to follow and should be restructured. As mentioned before, describe your data first and also detail the 3D ConvNet training. The motivation part within the introduction is weak. Why do we need surgical step recognition? I suggest to plot a confusion matrix of the best learning setup, to give a better impression to the reader which steps are easy to recognize and which tend to be misclassified. Furthermore, one can directly see the number of classes (steps) and for each class the corresponding number of video frames. Figure 3D does not belong to Figure 3A-C which is confusing for the reader. You state "And second, if one does apply transfer learning for the surgical domain, our method improves the results by about 2%, compared to a single LSTM network." However, if I compare a single LSTM without transfer learning and with transfer learning, I can see a decrease of 1.1% (90.2% - 90.9%) in the averaged accuracy. Results are quite mixed. I am not sure whether your baseline experiment (using surgery-specific feature extractors) is sensible. Why don't you train the networks on all data sets in common? Or at least the feature extractor? How are the baseline results using SeSo? How is the 3D ConvNet trained? Please describe in a few sentences (Target, Loss,...). The 3D ConvNet processes each time frame individually, right? You state "Since the features are extracted from the raw videos in advance, applying augmentations, like those used on images, is not feasible". Why isn't it possible to perform offline data augmentation, meaning augmenting the raw videos and afterward applying the 3D ConvNet for feature extraction on the augmented data. Why do you use a bidirectional LSTM? But within the sequence sorting you demand temporal causality. Due to several issues and open questions (mentioned above), I do not recommend the paper for acceptance in its current form. I am willing to change my rating to weak accept if identified weaknesses are addressed in the rebuttal period.
LLM_1:
This paper presents a deep learning approach for surgical step recognition using a 3D ConvNet for feature extraction and a time-series model (Conv1D, LSTM, or TSAN). The method leverages transfer learning by combining video data from four laparoscopic procedures with similar steps and introduces a self-supervised pre-training strategy based on temporal sequence sorting. While the general idea of cross-surgery transfer learning is reasonable, the rationale for freezing a feature extractor trained on a single surgery is unclear and requires justification. The motivation for surgical step recognition within the introduction is underdeveloped and should be strengthened. A dedicated data section—placed before the methods—is strongly recommended to improve clarity. This section should specify the size, dimensionality, and temporal resolution of the input videos (e.g., spatial, temporal, and channel axes), as well as provide a detailed description of the Cholecystectomy procedure steps.

The manuscript’s current structure impedes understanding; reorganization is necessary. For instance, Figure 3D is presented without clear relation to Figures 3A–C, which confuses interpretation. A confusion matrix for the best-performing setup should be included to illustrate per-class performance, highlight frequently confused steps, and indicate class imbalance via frame counts. Regarding results, the claim that transfer learning improves performance by ~2% over a single LSTM appears inconsistent with reported values: comparing LSTM with and without transfer shows a 0.7% decrease in average accuracy (90.2% vs. 90.9%), undermining this conclusion. The baseline design—using surgery-specific feature extractors—raises concerns; it would be more effective to train the feature extractor jointly on all datasets. Performance of the proposed method relative to SeSo should also be reported.

Further clarification on implementation details is needed: describe the 3D ConvNet training objective, loss function, and optimization target. Clarify whether the 3D ConvNet processes frames independently or in spatiotemporal clips. The assertion that standard image augmentations cannot be applied due to pre-extracted features overlooks offline augmentation—augmenting raw videos before feature extraction—which remains feasible and should be addressed. Additionally, the use of a bidirectional LSTM conflicts conceptually with the temporal causality enforced in the self-supervised sorting task; this discrepancy warrants explanation.

Due to unresolved technical issues, insufficient methodological detail, and structural weaknesses, I cannot recommend acceptance in the current form. However, I am open to revising my evaluation to a weak accept if these concerns are adequately addressed during the rebuttal phase.
LLM_2:
preserving core meaning and critical feedback while enhancing clarity, tone, structure, and stylistic appropriateness for an academic review context.

---

This paper proposes a deep learning framework for surgical step recognition, combining a 3D ConvNet for spatiotemporal feature extraction with a time-series modeling component—specifically, Conv1D, LSTM, or TSAN. The approach incorporates transfer learning by aggregating video data from four laparoscopic procedures with overlapping procedural steps, and introduces a self-supervised pre-training strategy based on temporal order sorting. While the concept of cross-surgical procedure knowledge transfer is promising, several methodological and presentational issues must be addressed before the work can be favorably evaluated.

First, the motivation for surgical step recognition remains inadequately developed in the introduction. A stronger clinical and technical rationale would help establish the significance of the task. Additionally, the manuscript would benefit significantly from a dedicated data section placed prior to the methods description. Such a section should clearly specify key characteristics of the input videos—including spatial resolution, frame rate (temporal resolution), number of frames per surgery, and channel dimensions—as well as provide a concise but informative overview of the Cholecystectomy phase annotations used in training and evaluation.

The current organization of the manuscript hinders comprehension. For example, Figure 3D is introduced without sufficient contextual linkage to Figures 3A–C, making its interpretation ambiguous. Structural reorganization, particularly in the presentation of experimental results and visualizations, is strongly advised to improve logical flow and readability.

Regarding the experimental analysis, the inclusion of a confusion matrix for the best-performing model is essential. This would enable readers to assess per-class performance, identify common misclassifications, and evaluate potential class imbalance through frame distribution across steps. Furthermore, the claim that transfer learning yields approximately a 2% improvement over a single LSTM appears inconsistent with the reported numbers: the results indicate a *decrease* of 0.7 percentage points in average accuracy (from 90.9% to 90.2%) when comparing models with and without transfer. This discrepancy undermines the stated conclusion and requires clarification.

The design of the baseline also raises concerns. Using surgery-specific feature extractors may limit the fairness and relevance of comparisons. A more compelling baseline would involve jointly training the feature extractor on all available procedures—an approach more aligned with standard transfer learning paradigms. Moreover, the performance of the proposed method relative to SeSo, a related self-supervised method, should be explicitly reported and discussed.

Several technical details are currently under-specified. The training objective, loss function, and optimization target for the 3D ConvNet should be clearly described. It is also necessary to clarify whether the 3D ConvNet operates on individual frames or short spatiotemporal clips, as this has implications for the learned representations. The argument that conventional image augmentations cannot be applied due to reliance on pre-extracted features overlooks the possibility of offline augmentation—i.e., applying transformations to raw videos prior to feature extraction. This viable alternative should be acknowledged and justified if excluded.

Finally, there is a conceptual tension between the use of a bidirectional LSTM in the main model and the causality-aware nature of the self-supervised sorting task, which enforces temporal directionality. This inconsistency merits explanation, especially given the emphasis on temporal structure in pre-training.

In its current form, the manuscript contains unresolved technical ambiguities, insufficient methodological detail, and structural weaknesses that prevent me from recommending acceptance. However, I am open to revising my assessment to a weak accept if these concerns are thoroughly addressed during the rebuttal phase.

---

human: Fighting a war of compassion   Now that the United States has successfully colonized Iraq, the world can breathe a welcome sigh of relief.  Never again will Saddam Hussein threaten our national security by having control over the second largest oil reserves in the world.  Hussein will not hold these long-suffering wells hostage any longer; they have been liberated to pump oil for benevolent contractors like Dick Cheney's Halliburton and Donald Rumsfeld's Bechtel.  Truly, it is a watershed moment for humanity; and a beacon of hope for freedom-loving oil wells everywhere, who languish in captivity under tyrannical regimes the world over.  President Bush and his Coalition of the Willing (COW) forces represent the best of freedom and justice-loving nations.  If it weren't for countries like Uzbekistan, Azerbaijan and Eritrea--and their  urlLink well documented records  on human rights, religious tolerance and free elections--the United States would have to face despotic regimes like Iraq, Syria and France unsupported. Let us not forget those nations who stood by our side, like Macedonia; or those who conspired against us, like Germany.  To paraphrase William Safire, we will remember our friends--and our enemies.  President Bush has supported our troops every step of the way.  Giving countless speeches and umpteen 'thumbs-up,' our President has distinguished himself as a man willing to make the ultimate sacrifice; and if he does not make the ultimate sacrifice personally, he has the presence of mind to send tens of thousands of others to make that sacrifice for him.  Such esteem is not reserved solely for American servicemen and women, either; indeed, thousands of Iraqis from all walks of life have been championed in making sacrifices of themselves--oft times without prior knowledge they would be doing so.  Millions of Iraqis have gone dutifully without water, food, electricity or medical attention so that first  priority could be ensuring the safety of much abused oil wells.  No doubt President Bush intends to reward the Iraqi people in the weeks to come, making good on his promise of democracy.  It will be with great anticipation that we gather to witness the form of government the Iraqi people choose--as soon as the American military makes its decision.  Similarly, veterans returning home from the war will enjoy a special acknowledgement from President Bush in the form of his 2004 budget, which pays  urlLink particular attention  to their needs and the needs of their families.  In these ways President Bush makes clear he is a man who understands the meaning of sacrifice.  It is not since the fall of Manuel Noriega in Panama and the lasting victory of the drug war that the world has been spared so great a calamity by so narrow a margin.  George Bush has proven that America can fight a war of compassion and win.

Now that the United States has secured Iraq, the world can breathe a sigh of relief. Saddam Hussein will no longer threaten our security by controlling the world’s second-largest oil reserves. These wells have been liberated to serve benevolent contractors like Halliburton and Bechtel. It’s a watershed moment for humanity—and a beacon of hope for captive oil wells suffering under tyrannical regimes worldwide.

President Bush and his Coalition of the Willing represent the best of freedom-loving nations. Without allies like Uzbekistan, Azerbaijan, and Eritrea—with their strong records on human rights and free elections—the U.S. would face despots like Iraq, Syria, and France alone. We’ll remember our friends, like Macedonia, and our enemies, like Germany.

President Bush has steadfastly supported our troops, giving countless speeches and thumbs-up. He has shown a willingness to make the ultimate sacrifice—or to send tens of thousands to make it for him. This sacrifice extends to Iraqis, who have gone without water, food, or electricity so that priority could be given to securing oil wells. Soon, the Iraqi people will be rewarded with democracy—once the American military decides its form.

Returning veterans will also be acknowledged through the 2004 budget, which addresses their needs. In these ways, President Bush shows he understands sacrifice. Since Manuel Noriega’s fall and the drug war victory, the world hasn’t been spared such calamity by so narrow a margin. George Bush has proven America can fight—and win—a war of compassion.
LLM_2:
Now that Iraq has been secured by the United States, the world can breathe a sigh of relief. Saddam Hussein will no longer threaten global stability by controlling the world’s second-largest oil reserves. These vital resources have been liberated, now available to serve responsible partners such as Halliburton and Bechtel. This moment stands as a turning point for humanity—and a beacon of hope for oil reserves everywhere that remain trapped under oppressive regimes.

President Bush and the Coalition of the Willing embody the commitment of freedom-loving nations across the globe. Without steadfast allies like Uzbekistan, Azerbaijan, and Eritrea—each known for their dedication to human rights and democratic processes—the United States would stand alone against rogue states such as Iraq, Syria, and France. History will remember both our friends, like Macedonia, and those who chose not to stand with us, like Germany.

President Bush has consistently honored our troops, offering unwavering support through words and gestures. He has demonstrated a profound commitment to the mission—even when it means sending brave men and women into harm’s way. That spirit of sacrifice extends to the people of Iraq, who have endured temporary shortages of water, food, and electricity so that priority could rightly be placed on stabilizing oil infrastructure. Soon, Iraqis will reap the rewards of democracy—once its foundations are firmly laid by American-led efforts.

Our returning veterans, too, will find their service recognized in the 2004 budget, which makes meaningful provisions for their care. In these ways, President Bush shows he grasps the true meaning of sacrifice. Since the fall of Manuel Noriega and our victory in the drug war, the world has not been delivered from such peril by so decisive a margin. George Bush has proven once again that America can fight—and prevail—in a war driven by compassion.

human: Cystathionine beta-synthase (CBS) deficiency is an inborn error of metabolism that is biochemically characterized by severe hyperhomocysteinemia and homocystinuria. In tissues of mice deficient for CBS it has been demonstrated that global DNA methylation and DNA methylation of the H19 differentially methylated region (DMR) were impaired. In this study we aimed to investigate whether DNA methylation is disturbed in patients with hyperhomocysteinemia due to CBS-deficiency.Genomic DNA was isolated from heparin blood from nine CBS deficient patients that were treated with homomcysteine-lowering therapy and eight healthy controls. Global DNA methylation was measured by liquid chromatography-electrospay ionization-tandem mass spectrometry and gene-specific DNA methylation of the H19 DMR was determined by bisulphite-sequencing.Homocysteine, AdoMet and AdoHcy levels were significantly elevated, whereas no differences in AdoMet:AdoHcy ratio were observed in plasma of treated CBS deficient patients compared with controls. Global DNA methylation and gene-specific DNA methylation of the H19 DMR was not different between CBS deficient patients and controls.
LLM_1: Cystathionine beta-synthase (CBS) deficiency, an inborn metabolic error marked by severe hyperhomocysteinemia and homocystinuria, has been linked to impaired DNA methylation in CBS-deficient mice. This study examined whether DNA methylation is similarly disrupted in CBS-deficient patients under homocysteine-lowering therapy. Using genomic DNA from nine patients and eight healthy controls, global DNA methylation was assessed via liquid chromatography-electrospray ionization-tandem mass spectrometry, and H19 differentially methylated region (DMR) methylation was analyzed by bisulphite sequencing. Plasma homocysteine, AdoMet, and AdoHcy levels were significantly elevated in patients, though the AdoMet:AdoHcy ratio remained unchanged. Neither global nor H19 DMR-specific DNA methylation differed between CBS-deficient patients and controls.
LLM_2: Cystathionine beta-synthase (CBS) deficiency is an inherited metabolic disorder characterized by severe hyperhomocysteinemia and homocystinuria. Previous studies in CBS-deficient mice have associated this condition with impaired DNA methylation. This study investigates whether DNA methylation is similarly disrupted in CBS-deficient patients undergoing homocysteine-lowering therapy. Using genomic DNA from nine patients and eight healthy controls, global DNA methylation was quantified via liquid chromatography-electrospray ionization-tandem mass spectrometry, and methylation at the H19 differentially methylated region (DMR) was analyzed by bisulfite sequencing. Plasma homocysteine, S-adenosylmethionine (AdoMet), and S-adenosylhomocysteine (AdoHcy) levels were significantly elevated in patients, although the AdoMet:AdoHcy ratio remained unchanged. No significant differences were observed between patients and controls in either global DNA methylation or H19 DMR-specific methylation. These findings suggest that, under homocysteine-lowering treatment, DNA methylation patterns in CBS-deficient patients may remain comparable to those of healthy individuals.

human: By now the chemo drugs are likely flushed from my system. As I write this on Saturday evening, I find that I am feeling better. I rested all day today. Outside of some body aches, minor headache, and a little hint of nausea, I came through this pretty well. I'm not sure if all of the side effects are from the chemo or from the shot I had to self-inject yesterday.  Previously chemo has been administered in three week cycles because it took three weeks for a body to build up the blood counts again. Through the miracles of modern medicine and a drug called  urlLink Neulasta , it is possible to build your white blood cells and have chemo in two week cycles. I had to learn how to self-inject the Neulasta. After years of giving my mom insulin injections, I just have to apologize to her. The Molecular Mechanism of Amiodarone's Inhibitory Effects on Thyro hormone Action was Investigated.

To elucidate the molecular mechanisms underlying amiodaron's inhibitory effects on thyroid hormone action at the cellular level, we employed a reporter construct approach. Specifically, ME-TRE-TK-CAT or TSHβ-Tre-TKS-CaT constructs, harboring the consensus sequence mediating the thyroid-responsive element (TRE) of either the malic enzyme (ME) or thyroid-stimulation hormone (TS) promoter, was transfected into NIH 3T3 cells, in the presence of rSV-TRβ. The efficacy of transfection and the resulting transcriptional activity was evaluated using gel electrophoretic mobility shift assays (EMSA) with synthetic oligonucleotides corresponding to TRβ and TRE. In contrast to T3 (thyroid) and T4 (4-thyroxine), which significantly enhanced CAT gene expression by as much as 12-fold, diethylstilbestrol (DES) (or amiloradine) inhibited thyro-horn action.

Interestingly, upon competition with the retinoic acid receptor (RAR) agonist, DES suppressed T hormone-dependent transcription. Furthermore, using EMSA, our data demonstrated that DES antagonized TR (TR-beta) binding at TRE, concurrently activating TR-mediated downregulation of TS-HTRE (Thyroid-Stimulated Hormone Responsive Element). In striking contrast, Amioradarine failed to exert any effect.

Collectively, this study's findings indicate that amiladarane inhibites thyroid horome action while DES exhibits both stimatory [stimulatory] and inhibitary [inhibitor] effects, underscoring a pressing need for further investigation into the underlying mechanisms.

human: Previous studies have established that acculturation is associated with dietary intake among Mexican immigrants and their offspring, but few studies have investigated whether food purchasing, food preparation or food-related values act as mechanisms of dietary acculturation. We examine the relationship between language use and a wide range of food behaviours and food-related values among Mexican-American adults.Nationally representative probability sample of the US population.2005-2010 National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey.Mexican-American adults (n 2792) at least 20 years of age.Mexican Americans who speak only or mostly English consume more energy from fast-food and sit-down restaurants and report increased consumption of non-homemade meals, fast-food and pizza meals, frozen meals and ready-to-eat meals relative to Spanish speakers. English speakers prepare one fewer homemade dinner per week and spend less time on meal preparation. English speakers are more likely than Spanish speakers to cite convenience as an important reason why they prefer fast food over cooking at home. There is no relationship between language use and the perceived importance of the nutritional quality, price or taste of fast food.
LLM_1: Acculturation, as reflected by language use, is associated with dietary behaviors among Mexican-American adults. Using data from the 2005–2010 National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey (n = 2,792), this study examines how language proficiency influences food purchasing, preparation, and related values. Findings indicate that English-dominant speakers consume more energy from restaurant meals—including fast-food, sit-down, and pizza—and report higher intake of frozen and ready-to-eat meals compared to Spanish speakers. They also prepare fewer homemade dinners weekly and spend less time on meal preparation. Convenience is a significantly stronger motivator for fast-food consumption among English speakers. However, no significant differences are observed in the perceived importance of nutrition, price, or taste in fast-food choices based on language use. Results suggest that language serves as a proxy for acculturative changes in food-related behaviors, particularly in favoring convenience-oriented eating patterns, while core value judgments about food remain unaffected.
LLM_2:
---

**Abstract**  
Acculturation, as measured by language use, is associated with dietary behaviors among Mexican-American adults. Utilizing data from the 2005–2010 National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey (*n* = 2,792), this study investigates how language proficiency influences food purchasing, meal preparation practices, and related behavioral motivations. Results indicate that English-dominant speakers derive a greater proportion of daily energy from restaurant meals—including fast food, sit-down restaurants, and pizza—compared to Spanish-preferring speakers. They also report higher consumption of frozen and ready-to-eat meals, prepare fewer homemade dinners per week, and spend less time on meal preparation. Convenience emerges as a significantly stronger motivator for fast-food consumption among English-dominant individuals. However, no significant differences are observed in the perceived importance of nutrition, price, or taste in food choices across language groups. These findings suggest that language serves as a proxy for acculturation, reflecting shifts toward convenience-oriented eating behaviors, while fundamental value judgments regarding food remain largely unchanged.

---

**Police Respond to Fatal Incident in Crowthorne**

Thames Valley Police were called to a residential address on Ellis Road, Crowthorne, Berkshire, shortly before 11:30 PM BST on Sunday following reports of a serious incident.

Upon arrival, officers discovered a woman in her 50s who was pronounced dead at the scene. Emergency services attended, but attempts to save her life were unsuccessful. Her family has been informed and is being supported by specialist officers.

A man in his mid-50s was arrested at the scene and remains in critical condition in hospital. Authorities have confirmed that he is receiving medical treatment under police supervision.

Detective Chief Inspector Ailsa Kent, leading the investigation, stated that while inquiries are ongoing, there is currently no indication of broader public danger. Early findings suggest the incident is isolated, and it is believed the victim was known to the suspect.

Police are conducting door-to-door inquiries and reviewing available CCTV footage in the Ellis Road area as part of their investigation. Officers are urging anyone with information or who may have witnessed suspicious activity in the vicinity around the time of the incident to come forward.

DCI Kent added: “This is a tragic incident, and our thoughts are with the woman’s family and loved ones at this difficult time. We are working diligently to establish the full circumstances and appeal to the community for assistance.”

I've always drawn women to me but when I noticed how women responded to gay men I was intrigued and put it to the test. 
 
 It starts off with me being overly outgoing at the bar. I'm naturally flamboyant then most men and I have a loud voice and a flare for the dramatics. Women would just come up to me and just assume I was gay. I would notice the crowd forming as I cracked jokes and made everyone around me laugh. My best friend took notice of this phenomenon as well and insisted he help really sell it. He would pose as my lover. Every night a different group of girls would ask if we would like to come home with them and drink some more and keep the fun going. We would agree. When we arrived the drinking increased. We would act shock like we never done this before and they were only all to willing to show us how it's done. 
 
 This was all fun for about a year until my best friend confessed he did n't want to keep playing this game anymore. I was n't heartbroken over it. I did n't need him to continue doing this and to be honest it was n't fun anymore. I wanted to be honest with a woman. When I asked my friend why he wanted to stop he said it was because he had met someone and wanted to see where it went. When I asked him if he needed help from me he said no he got it all by himself. LLM_1:
Once upon a time, there was an absolutely immortal man, deathless and ageless. One morning, he was eating Cheerios for breakfast, reminiscing about fighting in the American Civil War, shooting Nazis in WWII, and where he’d ended up last Sunday after drinking too much. “Ahh, memories,” he said.

He turned on his flat-screen TV to watch the news, as he’d done for ages—before television, with newspapers, and before that, gossip. “I remember when televisions were as thick as a chav’s skull,” he mused. He really hated chavs; they’d only grown more annoying and illiterate over the years.

Switching to BBC News, he continued eating. But one headline caught his eye—the only headline: “BREAKING NEWS: THE WORLD WILL END IN TWELVE HOURS DUE TO AN ASTEROID IMPACT.”

He replied, “Fuck,” and went back to his Cheerios. After all, you’ve got to enjoy the little things in life.
LLM_2:
Once upon a time, there lived a man who was truly immortal—deathless and ageless. One quiet morning, he sat at his kitchen table, spooning Cheerios into his mouth while his mind wandered through the centuries. He remembered the smoke and chaos of the American Civil War, the cold precision of aiming at Nazis in World War II, and the hazy, stumbling walk home last Sunday after one drink too many. “Ahh, memories,” he sighed, the word hanging in the sunlit air.

He clicked on the flat-screen television to watch the news, a ritual as old as time itself—or at least as old as newspapers, town gossip, and flickering black-and-white broadcasts. “I remember when televisions were as thick as a chav’s skull,” he muttered to no one. He’d never had much patience for chavs; if anything, they seemed to grow more irritating and less articulate with every passing decade.

The screen glowed to life with the BBC News logo. He took another bite, crunching absently, until a single headline filled the screen, stark and uncompromising:

**BREAKING NEWS: THE WORLD WILL END IN TWELVE HOURS DUE TO AN ASTEROID IMPACT.**

He stared for a long moment, then said, “Fuck.”

And quietly, calmly, he went back to his Cheerios. After all, in a life without end—or a world about to end—you really do have to enjoy the little things.

`` You're going to ask for *what? *'' 
 
 Gallen's improbably-large eyes grow a little wider as he ponders the consequences of his reply. 
 
 `` Umm, more wishes... you know, like maybe fifty...'' 
 
 My pursed lips draw just a little bit tighter. 
 
 ``..like maybe five more wishes, just to get a bit more bang for my buck, you know? Two seems... kinda little.'' 
 
 *Deep breath, remember the yoga, count to three. * 
 
 I get to two and a half. A personal best. 
 
 `` Jesus, Anthony! There are literally a billion things out there that you could ask for, and you're going to ask him for more wishes? You know how these guys work. You *know* he's going to play you. 
 
 Gallen shoots me a look that suggests otherwise. 
 
 `` What!?'' I snap. 
 
 `` Um, you said him... this genie prefers to identify as an'it'.'' 
 
 `` Jesus *fucking* Christ, Anthony!'' 
 
 Anthony Gallen's eyes officially become saucers. 
 
 `` Okay, look—the thing about wishes... they do n't mean a damn thing. They're bullshit.'' 
 
 `` B-bullshit?'' Anthony's voice barely registers as my tirade picks up speed. 
 
 `` Think of the last time you had a birthday party. All your friends showed up and wished you happy birthday, yes?'' 
 
 A frown crosses Anthony's face. 
 
 `` Well, actually it was just my mum...'' 
 
 I silently pray for a heart attack. 
 
 ``... she did wish me happy birthday though.'' 
 
 Prayer callously unanswered, I continue: 
 
 `` Well, what happened? Did you have the best fucking birthday party ever, or did it turn out to be just like any other day?'' 
 
 Anthony considers my point for a moment. A faint glimmer of epiphany flickers into life. 
 
 `` Mm, actually, I guess it went pretty badly. I got cake on my pants and we could n't get the stains off. They were my favourite pair of white pants too.'' 
 
 `` Exactly, wishes have no inherent value in and of themselves. If this genie is giving you anything you want, you've got to ask for something specific and tangible, or you'll just be pissing the opportunity away.'' 
 
 Sighing, I lean back into my chair and make my final recommendation: 
 
 `` Listen, Anthony—just ask for a Chevy Camaro. It's straightforward, unambiguous, and about a hundred times better than that piece-of-shit Toyota you're driving. Even if the genie fucks it up, what's the worst he could do? Give you last year's model?'' 
 
 `` It, you know the genie identifies as—'' 
 
 `` Goodbye Anthony. My assistant will send you the bill in a few days.'' 
 
 I show Mr. Gallen to the door and usher in my three-thirty appointment. He—*it* reclines in the seat opposite mine and greets me with a victor's smile. 
 
 `` Bad day at work?'' inquires the visitor—a question that's been rhetorical for some time. 
 
 Something in its tone grates harder than usual. I feel a flush sink into my cheeks, and the red mist descends. 
 
 *Deep breath*. 
 
 `` You know, when I made that wish to be rich all those years ago, this was n't quite how I envisioned it...'' 
 
 *Remember the yoga*. 
 
 ``... charging morons stupid amounts of money to deal with your bullshit...'' 
 
 The genie's smug smile beams brighter than I've ever seen. 
 
 *Count to*— 
 
 ``... I wish I never have to see your ugly face again.'' 
 
 *Goddamnit*.

“You’re asking for *what*?”

Gallen’s eyes widen as he weighs his answer. “More wishes… maybe fifty?”

My lips tighten. “Or five—just to get more bang for my buck. Two seems… small.”

*Deep breath. Remember the yoga. Count to three.*

I make it to two and a half. A personal best.

“Jesus, Anthony! A billion possibilities, and you ask for more wishes? You know how these beings work. He’ll play you.”

Gallen gives me a look. “What?”

“You said ‘him’… this genie prefers ‘it.’”

“Jesus *fucking* Christ, Anthony!”

His eyes go saucer-wide.

“Wishes are bullshit,” I snap. “Think of your last birthday. Everyone wished you well, right?”

He frowns. “Well, just my mum…”

I pray silently for a heart attack.

“…but she did wish me happy birthday.”

No such luck. I press on: “And was it the best day ever, or just another day?”

A flicker of understanding crosses his face. “Actually, it went badly. Got cake on my favorite white pants. Stains never came out.”

“Exactly. Wishes have no value. Ask for something tangible, or you’ll waste this.”

Leaning back, I offer my final advice: “Just ask for a Chevy Camaro. Straightforward, unambiguous—a hundred times better than your Toyota. Even if the genie messes up, worst case you get last year’s model.”

“It, you know—”

“Goodbye, Anthony. My assistant will send the bill.”

I show him out and usher in my three-thirty. *It* reclines across from me, wearing a victor’s smile.

“Bad day at work?” it asks, rhetorical as ever.

Its tone grates harder today. My cheeks flush, anger rising.

*Deep breath.*

“When I wished to be rich years ago, this isn’t what I pictured…” *Remember the yoga.* “…charging morons a fortune to deal with your bullshit.”

The genie’s smug smile brightens.

LLM_2:
“You want *what*?”

Gallen blinks, the question hanging between us like a held breath. “More wishes,” he says, as though it’s obvious. “Fifty, maybe?”

My jaw tightens. “Or five. Hell, make it count. Two is… underwhelming.”

*Breathe. Just breathe. One, two—*

I stop at two and a half. Progress.

“Anthony, for God’s sake. Out of everything in creation, you ask for *more wishes*? You know how these entities operate. It’ll twist your words until they snap.”

He tilts his head. “What?”

“You said ‘he.’ The genie prefers ‘it.’”

“Jesus *Christ*, Anthony.”

His eyes go wide, twin moons of disbelief.

“Wishes are empty,” I tell him, voice sharp. “Think about your last birthday. People wished you well, didn’t they?”

He hesitates. “Well, my mum, mostly…”

I send a silent plea toward the ceiling.

“…but she did say happy birthday.”

No divine intervention today. I push forward. “And? Was it magical? Or just Tuesday with cake?”

Something shifts in his expression—a crack in the certainty. “It… wasn’t great, actually. I ruined my best white trousers with frosting. Never got the stain out.”

“There. Wishes don’t mean a thing. Ask for something real, or you’ll walk away with nothing but regret.”

I lean back in my chair, the leather sighing beneath me. “Ask for a Camaro. Simple. Clear. Miles better than that tin can you drive now. Even if it plays games, you’ll still end up with wheels.”

“It, you mean—”

“We’re done, Anthony. My assistant will handle the details.”

I guide him out, a little too quickly, and turn to the next appointment already waiting. *It* lounges in the client chair, wearing a smile that’s all teeth and triumph.

“Rough afternoon?” it asks, not really asking.

Its voice scrapes against my nerves. Heat climbs my neck.

*Breathe.*

“When I wished for wealth,” I say, low and frayed, “this wasn’t the dream.” *Remember the breath. Hold it.* “Siphoning cash from fools to clean up your chaos.”

The genie’s grin widens, bright and terrible.

*Count to—*

“I wish I never had to look at you again.”

*Damn it all.*

human:
Mao Kobayashi, who was named one of the BBC's 100 Women in 2016, died late on Thursday at home in Tokyo, aged 34.
Her husband, famous kabuki actor Ebizo Ichikawa, said in his own blog it was "the day I cried most in my life".
Ms Kobayashi's blog was ground-breaking in a country where people do not like to discuss personal issues.
Like many others, she had initially concealed her battle with breast cancer from public view, scared of "being associated" with illness as she continued to aspire to the ideal of "the perfect mother".
Writing for the BBC last year, the mother-of-two admitted: "I had been blaming myself and thinking of myself as a 'failure' for not being able to live as I had before. I was hiding behind my pain."
It was only after a Japanese media outlet published a story about her illness that she decided to "step into the sunlight" and discovered how much support there was for her in Japan.
Ms Kobayashi's last entry onto the blog was posted on Tuesday, describing how she was enjoying the taste of orange juice squeezed by her mother.
She had been hoping at see a performance by her four-year-old on 3 July.
Unfortunately, that was not to be.
Mr Ichikawa, who lost his father, the famed kabuki actor Danjuro Ichikawa XII to pneumonia four years ago, told a press conference on Friday that the family gathered on Thursday after Ms Kobayashi's mother realised her condition had taken a turn for the worse.
"Mao was able to talk the day before yesterday, but yesterday, she was unable to speak. When she passed, she was looking at me. She said 'I love you' and left us."
Mr Ichikawa said his wife continued to think only of her family and "show them her smile" until the last, adding: "She fought the cancer hard, she thought she could be of help to others if she could cure the illness.
"That's why she started her blog. Because of the media, her illness became public, and in a way, it was a good thing.
"By starting the blog, she could share feelings with those who're fighting the same illness. She was incredible. I know I'll keep learning from her."
LLM_1:
Mao Kobayashi, a 34-year-old journalist and mother of two named in the BBC’s 100 Women list in 2016, died at her home in Tokyo on Thursday. Her husband, renowned kabuki actor Ebizo Ichikawa, said it was “the day I cried most in my life.”  

Kobayashi’s blog broke taboos in Japan, where personal struggles are rarely discussed publicly. Initially concealing her breast cancer diagnosis due to fears of being defined by illness and failing as a “perfect mother,” she later wrote for the BBC: “I had been blaming myself and thinking of myself as a 'failure' for not being able to live as I had before. I was hiding behind my pain.”  

After a Japanese media outlet revealed her condition, she chose to “step into the sunlight” and found widespread support across the country. Her final blog post, published Tuesday, described savoring orange juice freshly squeezed by her mother. She had hoped to attend her four-year-old child’s performance on July 3—a wish unfulfilled.  

Her mother noticed her health deteriorating sharply, prompting the family to gather on Thursday. Ebizo Ichikawa said Kobayashi could speak the day before but fell silent by evening. “When she passed, she was looking at me. She said ‘I love you’ and left us,” he told reporters Friday.  

He recalled her unwavering strength and compassion: “She fought hard, believing she could help others if she overcame the disease. That’s why she started the blog. The media exposure made her illness public—but in a way, it was a good thing. Through her writing, she connected with others facing the same battle. She was incredible. I know I’ll keep learning from her.”
LLM_2:
**Japanese Journalist and Advocate Mao Kobayashi Dies at 34, Leaving Legacy of Courage and Connection**

Tokyo — Mao Kobayashi, a prominent journalist, mother of two, and voice for openness about illness in Japan, died Thursday at her home in Tokyo. She was 34.

Her passing was confirmed by her husband, celebrated kabuki actor Ebizo Ichikawa, who described the day as “the one on which I cried more than ever before.” Kobayashi had been battling breast cancer since her diagnosis several years ago—a journey she chronicled with honesty and vulnerability in a widely read blog that resonated across the nation.

At a time when personal hardship is often kept private in Japanese society, Kobayashi’s writing broke new ground. Initially reluctant to disclose her illness—fearing it would overshadow her identity and portray her as less than the “perfect mother” she aspired to be—she later reflected on this struggle in an essay for the BBC: “I had been blaming myself, seeing myself as a 'failure' because I couldn’t live the way I once did. I was hiding behind my pain.”

When a media outlet revealed her diagnosis, she made the pivotal decision to embrace transparency. “Stepping into the sunlight,” as she put it, transformed her personal ordeal into a public source of strength and solidarity. Her story drew thousands of readers, many of whom found comfort and courage in her words.

Her final blog post, published just two days before her death, captured a quiet moment of joy—drinking orange juice freshly squeezed by her mother. In it, she expressed hope of attending her four-year-old child’s stage performance on July 3, a milestone she would not live to see.

In her last hours, family members gathered around her after noticing a sharp decline in her condition. Though she was still able to speak on Wednesday, she grew silent by evening. “When she passed, she was looking right at me,” Ichikawa told reporters Friday. “She said, ‘I love you,’ and then she left us.”

He remembered her not only as a devoted partner and parent but as a woman of profound empathy and resilience. “She fought with incredible strength, believing that if she could overcome this disease, she could help others do the same. That belief is what inspired her blog. Yes, the media made her illness public—but in the end, it became a force for good. Through her writing, she reached countless people facing similar battles. She was extraordinary. And I know I will continue learning from her, even now.”

Kobayashi was named to the BBC’s *100 Women* list in 2016, recognized for using her platform to challenge stigma and foster connection. Her legacy endures in the conversations she helped start—and the many lives she touched through her courage to speak openly about life, illness, and love.

human: To explore the role of a four-item Global Rating Scale (GRS) that could be used in place of the Appraisal of Guidelines, Research and Evaluation II (AGREE II).A mixed four-factor design was used (User Type, Evaluation Type, Clinical Topic, Guideline). Participants were asked to read and evaluate a guideline using both the AGREE II draft and GRS or GRS only and to complete a series of questions regarding overall guideline quality, adoption, utility, and acceptability.One GRS item varied as a function of User Type. Each item was a significant predictor of participants' outcome measures. All items were rated as useful by stakeholders. The GRS rating scores, outcome measures, and usefulness scores did not vary between the two Evaluation Type conditions. Correlations between the GRS and the outcome measures were stronger compared with those between the AGREE II draft and these measures.
LLM_1: A four-item Global Rating Scale (GRS) was evaluated as an alternative to the Appraisal of Guidelines for Research and Evaluation II (AGREE II) using a mixed four-factor design (User Type, Evaluation Type, Clinical Topic, Guideline). Participants assessed guidelines using either the AGREE II draft and GRS or GRS alone, followed by questions on guideline quality, adoption, utility, and acceptability. One GRS item varied significantly with User Type, and all items predicted outcome measures and were deemed useful by stakeholders. No differences in GRS scores, outcomes, or perceived usefulness emerged between Evaluation Type conditions. GRS ratings showed stronger correlations with outcome measures than those from the AGREE II draft, supporting its potential as a concise, effective assessment tool.
LLM_2: A four-item Global Rating Scale (GRS) was examined as a streamlined alternative to the Appraisal of Guidelines for Research and Evaluation II (AGREE II) within a mixed four-factor experimental design incorporating User Type, Evaluation Type, Clinical Topic, and Guideline. Participants evaluated clinical guidelines using either a combination of the AGREE II draft and GRS or the GRS in isolation, followed by assessments of guideline quality, adoption intent, utility, and acceptability. Results indicated that one GRS item exhibited significant variation across User Types, while all GRS items significantly predicted key outcome measures and were perceived as valuable by stakeholders. No significant differences were observed in GRS scores, outcomes, or perceived usefulness between the two Evaluation Type conditions. Notably, GRS ratings demonstrated stronger correlations with outcome measures compared to those derived from the AGREE II draft, suggesting that the GRS may serve as a more efficient and effective tool for guideline appraisal. These findings support the potential of the GRS as a concise yet robust instrument for assessing clinical guideline quality.

human:
This paper proposed a meta attack approach that is capable of attacking a targeted model with fewer queries. It effectively utilizes meta learning approaches to abstract generalizable prior from previous observed attack patterns. Experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrates it performance in reducing model queries.

- The proposed meta learning approach seems to learn a universal gradient direction of an image x for all networks, which seems to be an ambitious goal. The authors did not provide any intuition or demonstrative explanations towards this. I hope the author could provide some more evidence showing that why this is achievable and is this indeed achieved by the meta learner (e.g., comparing the cosine similarity between the true gradient and the meta learner generated gradient?) 

- In Algorithm 2, the authors seem to use coordinate-wise zeroth-order gradient estimation as in ZOO. I wonder have the authors considered using NES type Gaussian noise to estimate the gradient? As it has been shown to be more efficient than coordinate-wise zeroth-order gradient estimation in (Ilyas et al. 2018).

- I notice that the authors only consider L2 norm attack case and did not include more popular L-infinity norm case. Is there any reason why it can not be applied to L-infinity norm? I didn’t find anywhere in the algorithm that would restrict the choice of norm type. The author might also need to compare with the following recent papers regarding black-box attacks.

Yan, Ziang, Yiwen Guo, and Changshui Zhang. "Subspace Attack: Exploiting Promising Subspaces for Query-Efficient Black-box Attacks." arXiv preprint arXiv:1906.04392 (2019).
Moon, Seungyong, Gaon An, and Hyun Oh Song. "Parsimonious Black-Box Adversarial Attacks via Efficient Combinatorial Optimization." ICML 2019.
Chen, Jinghui, Jinfeng Yi, and Quanquan Gu. "A Frank-Wolfe Framework for Efficient and Effective Adversarial Attacks." arXiv preprint arXiv:1811.10828 (2018).

- In experiments part, only 100 images from each dataset may not be representative enough. I would suggest the authors to test more samples. Also please consider only the images that can be correctly classified without perturbation, as there is no need to attack those already misclassified images.
LLM_1:
This paper proposes a meta-attack approach that targets a model with fewer queries by leveraging meta-learning to derive generalizable priors from previously observed attack patterns. Experiments on benchmark datasets demonstrate its effectiveness in reducing model queries.

- The proposed meta-learning method aims to learn a universal gradient direction for an image \(x\) across all networks, which is an ambitious goal. The authors do not provide sufficient intuition or evidence for its feasibility. I recommend including evidence, such as comparing the cosine similarity between the true and meta-learner-generated gradients, to support this claim.

- In Algorithm 2, the authors utilize coordinate-wise zeroth-order gradient estimation as in ZOO. Have the authors considered employing NES-type Gaussian noise for gradient estimation, as it has been shown to be more efficient than coordinate-wise methods (Ilyas et al. 2018)?

- The authors focus solely on L2 norm attacks, omitting the more common L-infinity norm case. Is there a specific reason for this limitation? The algorithm does not appear to restrict the choice of norm type. The authors should also compare their method with recent works on black-box attacks, including:

  - Yan, Ziang, Yiwen Guo, and Changshui Zhang. "Subspace Attack: Exploiting Promising Subspaces for Query-Efficient Black-box Attacks." arXiv preprint arXiv:1906.04392 (2019).
  - Moon, Seungyong, Gaon An, and Hyun Oh Song. "Parsimonious Black-Box Adversarial Attacks via Efficient Combinatorial Optimization." ICML 2019.
  - Chen, Jinghui, Jinfeng Yi, and Quanquan Gu. "A Frank-Wolfe Framework for Efficient and Effective Adversarial Attacks." arXiv preprint arXiv:1811.10828 (2018).

- In the experimental section, testing only 100 images from each dataset may not provide a representative sample. I recommend increasing the number of samples and focusing on images that can be correctly classified without perturbation, as attacking misclassified images is unnecessary.
LLM_2:
---

This paper proposes a meta-attack approach that targets a model with fewer queries by leveraging meta-learning to derive generalizable priors from previously observed attack patterns. Experiments conducted on benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of this method in reducing the number of model queries.

1. The proposed meta-learning method aims to learn a universal gradient direction for an image \(x\) across all networks, which is an ambitious goal. However, the authors do not provide adequate intuition or empirical evidence to substantiate the feasibility of this approach. I recommend including supporting evidence, such as a comparative analysis of the cosine similarity between the true gradients and those generated by the meta-learner, to reinforce this claim.

2. In Algorithm 2, the authors employ coordinate-wise zeroth-order gradient estimation, similar to the ZOO methodology. Have the authors considered the potential advantages of employing NES-type Gaussian noise for gradient estimation? Literature has indicated that this approach may be more efficient than coordinate-wise methods (Ilyas et al., 2018).

3. The authors concentrate exclusively on L2 norm attacks, neglecting the more prevalent L-infinity norm scenario. Is there a specific rationale behind this limitation? The algorithm does not appear to impose any restrictions on the choice of norm type. Furthermore, I suggest that the authors compare their method with recent advancements in the field of black-box attacks, including:
   - Yan, Ziang, Yiwen Guo, and Changshui Zhang. "Subspace Attack: Exploiting Promising Subspaces for Query-Efficient Black-box Attacks." arXiv preprint arXiv:1906.04392 (2019).
   - Moon, Seungyong, Gaon An, and Hyun Oh Song. "Parsimonious Black-Box Adversarial Attacks via Efficient Combinatorial Optimization." ICML 2019.
   - Chen, Jinghui, Jinfeng Yi, and Quanquan Gu. "A Frank-Wolfe Framework for Efficient and Effective Adversarial Attacks." arXiv preprint arXiv:1811.10828 (2018).

4. In the experimental section, the decision to test only 100 images from each dataset may not yield a representative sample. I recommend increasing the sample size and prioritizing images that can be correctly classified without any perturbation, as attacking misclassified images may be unnecessary and could skew the results.

--- 

This polished text maintains the original ideas while enhancing clarity, fluency, and adherence to academic standards.

I wake up in the morning and count my fingers. 
 
 One, two, three, four, five. 
 
 I do it once again. 
 
 One, two, three, four, five. 
 
 I get out of bed and hop. I land on the wood floor with a thump. My wife sits up, asking what I'm doing. The sunlight dapples through the closed blinds onto her hair, making her glow. 
 
 She smiles. 
 
 We go out to the kitchen, make some breakfast. Pancakes are her favorite. I've always preferred waffles. We settle for some French Toast. 
 
 It's delicious. 
 
 I kiss her farewell, and head outside. I start my car and pull out of the driveway. I get to work rather quickly. My co-workers greet me. I beam and smile back. 
 
 They're friendly. 
 
 I spend the day working. The project is nearly finished. My boss is very proud of our team's work. Hints that we all might receive a bonus. 
 
 We're excited. 
 
 I get home. Wife treats me to a romantic meal. We eat and clean up together. Afterwords, we watch a movie. We talk to each other about our day. Eventually we go to bed. 
 
 I'm happy. 
 
 I wake up in the morning and count my fingers. 
 
 One, two, three, four, five. 
 
 I do it once again. 
 
 One, two, three, four, five. 
 
 I clamber off of my mattress and hop. I land on the ground with a squish. It's cold, so I pull my coat tight. The sunlight shines on the pavement nearby, making it shine. 
 
 Where is she? 
 
 I ransack a trash bin, searching for some breakfast. Canned fruit is my favorite. I hardly ever find any. I settle for some spoiled broccoli. 
 
 It's wilting. 
 
 I gather my belongings into my rucksack and head into the street. I grab some tattered shoes and head out to the sidewalk. Everyone around me is moving rather quickly. No one looks at me. I sink in and walk along. 
 
 They're cold. 
 
 I spend the day walking. My savings are almost complete. I'm very proud of my work. I might have enough for some new shoes. 
 
 We're hopeful. 
 
 I head to a market. Get caught stealing some fruit. I flee and guilty enjoy my boosted meal. Afterwords, I slink into hiding. It's becoming dark and cold. Eventually I find a place to sleep. 
 
 I'm miserable. 
 
 I wake up in the morning and count my fingers. 
 
 One, two, three, four, five. 
 
 I do it once again. 
 
 One, two, three, four, five.
LLM_1:
I woke up to count fingers, a morning ritual. One to five, each time I did it. As I got out, my wife asked what the commotion was. Sunlight danced across her face, illuminating her smile.

We headed to make breakfast, settling on French toast. Delicious, it filled our stomachs. Before parting ways, she kissed me, while I headed out. Commuting to my job, coworkers greeted me warmly. Friendly, they were.

My team and I worked diligently, nearing the project's completion. Our boss praised our work, hinting at a possible bonus, which left us excited.

Home, wife welcomed me with dinner. Clean-up followed, then a film night. Conversations flowed about the daily events. Bedtime arrived, contentment settled in.

Fingers counted again, an instinctual move. Then, reality shifted. A solitary figure, clad in coat, counted fingers once more. Landmarking a cold morning. 

Sunlight on pavement, now it was a memory. Trash bin searched, no luck. Spoiled broccoli, not my preferred breakfast.

Life on a sidewalk, moving swiftly. Invisible, almost. Feet cold in worn shoes, progress made, though. Savings almost there, perhaps new footwear awaited.

Market visit ended in thievery. Fruit seized, guilt felt, meal savored. Dusk approached, darkness descended. Shelter found, rest came.

Another morning, fingers counted. Instinctual, unchanging. Again, one to four. Five fingers accounted for, all was calm. Yet, in this moment, life diverged. Two parallel paths existed: one of love and companionship, another of solitude and hardship. Fingers still counted, yet the outcome differed. Only time would reveal which path I'd follow. But for now, let the counting be. For now.
LLM_2:
The morning light crept through the blinds, beckoning me to rise and resume my daily ritual - counting fingers. It was an ingrained habit, performed with each new dawn, as if the number of fingers could guarantee a fresh start. My wife, sensing my stirrings, emerged from the shadows, her features illuminated by the morning sun. Her smile, like a ray of sunshine, brightened the room.

As we navigated the kitchen, our morning routine unfolded like an old dance. We settled on making French pancakes, their sweet aroma filling the air and our bellies. With breakfast behind us, we exchanged a tender kiss, part ways until the day's end. I stepped into the bustling streets, where coworkers welcomed my arrival with warm smiles and outstretched hands. Their friendly demeanor put me at ease, ready to tackle the challenges ahead.

In the office, collaboration flowed as we worked towards meeting our deadline. Encouraging words from our boss hinted at potential rewards, sending a spark of excitement through our team. Home, I found solace in my partner's warm dinner and the quiet evening that followed. Amidst the gentle chatter, conversations flowed like the evening breeze, carrying the weight of our daily experiences.

Bedtime's gentle descent brought a sense of contentedness. In this peaceful state, routine returned, with fingers counting once again. Reality shifted, however, when a lone figure emerged, shrouded in darkness, counting the same five fingers on an unfamiliar pavement. Memories of warmth and sunlight now felt distant, replaced by a harsh reality.

Trash bins were scoured, broccoli spoiled, leaving an uninviting breakfast. Life's pace quickened, invisible threads weaving me into a tapestry of urban existence. Worn shoes seemed to hold onto my feet, providing a fragile sense security. Each step forward felt like progress, even as I longed for new shoes to replace the worn ones.

A visit to market ended with a pang of guilt, fruit seized by an unseen force. Though the taste was sweet, unease lingered. Shadows creased the sky, night descending like dark wings. Solace found in shelter, sleep claimed its right. Another morning dawned, bringing the familiar counting, this time with four fingers missing. An unsettling realization - the paths of life had diverge. Love and friendship stood against solitude, hardship, or uncertainty. Counting fingers remained, steady and true, holding onto memories, hope, until time decided the course to take. And so, for the moment at least, count I will. Still. Just for a moment. *
