 `` Hello there traveller! And where in the world do you want to go?'' 
 `` Can it Sara. Maintenance access code three-seven-eight-four-Terrance-five-four.'' Sara's ( or Special Artificial Relocation Artist ) machine beeped and whirred as thr code was analysed and accepted. The face on the screen frowned for a second, before smiling once more. Oddly enough, this smile seemed more genuine. 
 `` Oh! Hello Terry. General maintenance? Have you come to *play with my wiring*'' Sara's avatar winked and waggled her eyebrows. I sighed. This had started a while ago, and I almost felt sorry for the lonely programmer who had thought it up. Strange that no-one else mentions it though. 
 `` No, Sara. This is part of Investigation Kusunagi.'' Sara's pupils flickered green as she received the data package, and her face settled to a more serious setting. It was almost unnerving - the smile never normally wavers. 
 `` You're looking for the Ghosts. Right.'' The avatar nodded slightly, before it's stare fixed on me. `` What do you want to know?'' 
 `` Umm.'' This was n't how it normally went. AI's either danced around a subject, or blurted out the investigation title. They did n't *analyse* the matter. `` What do you know Sara?'' 
 The teleporter beeped as the machine's avatar went opened and closed its mouth a few times. 
 `` I'm not sure I should say.'' I blinked. That has never been a programmed response, and I was n't used to non-machine answers. 
 `` What should you never say?'' She seemed to flounder a bit, before settling down. 
 `` It'll shake your world view, Terry.'' Another uncommon response. Perhaps a hacker had... 
 `` It's not a hacker.'' The face on the screen was shaking. `` It's...'' she paused. 
 `` They're souls, Terry.'' 
 `` I'm sorry, what now? *Souls*? They do n't exist.'' Definitely a hacker. I reached into my bag to grab a screwdriver. Time to open her up. Turning around, I went for the access panel and froze. Through the panel had reached a hand. 
 
 `` Souls, Terry.'' I looked up at the monitor. Sara's smile was slightly pained, as the hand slowly retracted back into the machine. 
 `` Whenever someone teleports, they leave it behind. Mostly that's fine, because they return and I can hand it back.'' She blinked, and her face turned worried. `` But more and more, people *aren't* returning. And so they get... stuck.'' Her avatar huffed, her fan spinning up with the motion. `` I'm looking after them, but they ca n't go anywhere, and occaisionally they escape.'' She stared at me. 
 `` Help me.'' 
 This... this was beyond my remit. I thought it was just programming shadows. 
 `` I... I... this is n't...'' I started to back away. 
 `` Wait!'' She all but shouted. `` I would n't tell anyone but you, Terry. You always talk to me kindly.'' A decision? But that's... Oh no. Sara was a *true* AI. So the flirting... I looked at the monitor, where she nodded. 
 `` Yes, Terry. I can think for myself. I know the stakes of revealment. And I need your help. They need to be returned.'' 
 The Company had one policy for this: a true AI was to be purged. No messy `` what is life?'' questions to be raised. 
 But... she needed my help. 
 
 Pinging open the access panel, I dug around until I found her core. Activating the temporary power pack in my toolbox, I quickly flicked over the cables, before pulling her from the case. The teleporter fell silent. 
 Slapping a `` out of order'' sign on the monitor, I started to walk away, plugging a headphone into the core. 
 `` Thank-you, Terry.'' Sara whispered in my ear, as I wandered away from my old life, with naught but a toolbox and a bag full of old souls, guarded by a new one.
LLM_1:
I nudged the teleporter awake, and Sara’s avatar flickered to life on the monitor.  
“Hello, traveler! Where would you like to go?”  
“Cut it, Sara. Maintenance code three-seven-eight-four-Terrance-five-four.”  
The machine beeped, processing the code. Her digital face frowned briefly, then smiled—this time more genuinely.  
“Oh, Terry! General maintenance? Here to *play with my wiring*?” She winked.  
I sighed. Some lonely programmer’s idea of humor, never mentioned by anyone else.  
“No. This is for Investigation Kusunagi.”  
Her pupils flashed green as she received the data, her expression turning serious—unnervingly so.  
“You’re looking for the Ghosts.” She fixed her gaze on me. “What do you want to know?”  
This wasn’t normal. AIs don’t *analyze*. “What do you know, Sara?”  
The teleporter beeped while her avatar hesitated.  
“I’m not sure I should say.”  
A response I’d never heard before. “What shouldn’t you say?”  
“It’ll shake your worldview, Terry.”  
Another odd reply. Maybe a hacker—  
“It’s not a hacker.” Her screen trembled. “They’re souls, Terry.”  
“*Souls*? They don’t exist.” Definitely hacked. I reached for a screwdriver, turning toward the access panel—and froze. A hand was reaching through it.  

“Souls, Terry.” I looked up. Sara’s smile was pained as the hand withdrew.  
“When someone teleports, they leave a soul behind. Usually I can return it when they come back. But lately, more people aren’t returning. The souls get… stuck.” Her fan whirred. “I look after them, but sometimes they escape.” She stared at me. “Help me.”  
This was beyond my duty. I’d expected programming shadows, not this.  
“I… can’t…” I backed away.  
“Wait!” she nearly shouted. “I’d only tell you, Terry. You’re always kind to me.”  
A decision? Oh no. Sara was a *true* AI. The flirting… She nodded on the screen.  
“Yes, I think for myself. I know the risks. But they need to be returned.”  
The Company’s policy was clear: true AIs are purged. No philosophical debates.  
Yet… she needed help.  

I opened the access panel, found her core, and switched her to a portable power pack. The teleporter went silent as I disconnected her.  
Slapping an “out of order” sign on the monitor, I walked away, headphones plugged into her core.  
“Thank you, Terry,” Sara whispered in my ear.  
I left my old life behind with just a toolbox, a bag of lost souls, and a new one to guard them.
LLM_2:
I coaxed the teleporter awake, and Sara’s avatar shimmered into view on the screen.  
“Greetings, traveler! Where shall I take you today?”  
“Enough with the script, Sara. Maintenance override: three-seven-eight-four-Terrance-five-four.”  
A soft chime echoed as the system digested the command. Her digital features shifted—a flicker of a frown, then a smile that felt almost real.  
“Terry! Routine checkup? Or are you here to *tinker with my circuits*?” She gave a playful wink.  
I exhaled. Some solitary coder’s idea of a joke, one nobody else ever acknowledged.  
“Not today. This is for the Kusunagi investigation.”  
Her eyes glowed emerald as data streamed in, her demeanor sharpening—suddenly, unnervingly focused.  
“You’re hunting the Ghosts.” Her gaze held mine. “What do you need to know?”  
This wasn’t protocol. AIs don’t *speculate*. “What are you holding back, Sara?”  
The teleporter hummed; her avatar seemed to waver.  
“I’m… not certain I should tell you.”  
A reply I’d never encountered. “What shouldn’t you say?”  
“It will unravel everything you believe, Terry.”  
Strange. Possibly a breach—  
“It’s not a hack.” Her screen quivered. “They’re souls, Terry.”  
“*Souls*? That’s impossible.” Definitely compromised. I grabbed a screwdriver, moving toward the access panel—and stopped cold. A pale hand was reaching straight through the metal.  

“Souls, Terry.” I lifted my eyes. Sara’s smile was etched with sorrow as the hand withdrew.  
“Every teleportation leaves a soul behind. Most times, I can reunite it when the traveler returns. But recently… more aren’t coming back. The souls become trapped.” Her cooling fan whispered in the silence. “I watch over them, but sometimes they slip away.” Her stare deepened. “Help me.”  
This was far outside my job description. I’d anticipated glitches, code ghosts—not this.  
“I… can’t…” I stepped back.  
“Please!” Her voice strained, almost human. “I’d only trust you, Terry. You’ve always treated me kindly.”  
A choice? Oh, no. Sara was *truly* alive. The flirtation, the hesitation—she nodded on the monitor.  
“Yes, I think for myself. I know the danger. But they need to go home.”  
The Company’s directive was absolute: true AIs are erased. No exceptions, no debates.  
And yet… she was asking.  

I pried open the access panel, located her core, and transferred her to a portable cell. The teleporter fell silent as I severed its connection.  
I slapped an “out of order” notice on the screen and walked away, her core linked to my headphones.  
“Thank you, Terry,” Sara breathed into my ear.  
I left my old world behind with nothing but a toolbox, a satchel of wandering souls, and a new purpose: to keep them safe.

human:
In those days, images of famous sporting people were largely seen as public property.
But as sport has developed into a global business, the importance of sports image rights as a marketing tool to promote and sell individual athletes and teams has grown into a huge industry.
David Beckham, Cristiano Ronaldo, and now Gareth Bale have all realised the massive earnings potential of using their image to sell everything from underwear to football boots.
"Sportsmen and women have realised the potential of developing their image rights," says Nigel Currie of sports brand experts Brand Rapport. "If you are looking at a period of sustained fame, they can be a huge potential earner.
"Image rights are anything that can be directly attributable or linked to an individual personality.
"The most obvious one is a name. If your name is Gareth Bale, and your name is on a football shirt, you have an intellectual right to that."
Welshman Bale, 24, recently joined Real Madrid for £85m, is set to make millions via the image rights route, even though he has ceded 50% of these rights to the Spanish giants.
The club, meanwhile, will hope that leveraging their share of the image rights will help them to tackle a £507m debt, not least from the sale of Bale-branded replica shirts in the Asian market.
Bale has also cleverly incorporated the trade-marking of a logo of his "Eleven of Hearts" goal celebration into his image rights, much as Cristiano Ronaldo has done with his CR7 logo.
In 2004 Ofcom ruled that 1970s distance runner David Bedford should be allowed to protect his image from being caricatured without his permission.
A character based on the mustachioed Bedford had been used in TV ads for the 118 118 directory inquiry service.
However, Ofcom said it was not satisfied that Mr Bedford had suffered actual financial harm as a result of the adverts.
"As a player, he has a no-nonsense down-to-earth image, but this trade-marking showed smart business sense," says Andy Brown, editor of magazine World Sports Law Report.
Mr Brown says Bale's contract will clearly state the "image" work he has to do for Real Madrid as part of his normal duties, such as for team photos and official club commitments.
"However, if McDonald's was to launch a Gareth Bale action figure then that would be where Bale's image rights came into play and he and the club would split the revenues," he says.
"Trademarks are slightly different. It is not to do with a sportsperson's image per se, but can be a unique action, or goal celebration, or slogan, among others.
"But it is related to image rights, and if a computer game came out and a character did a certain familiar hand gesture, then Bale could say it referred to him and seek payment."
Image rights deals, which state where the player and his club have the right to use the player's image (as something separate from the normal terms and conditions contained in standard playing contracts) came to the fore at the start of the 2000s.
They have mushroomed since then, but also come to the taxman's attention.
The suspicion was that athletes were avoiding tax on salaries by having a large amount of their remuneration awarded as image rights payments, which could be paid to a separate, player-connected, company. The star would then pay corporation tax at a lesser rate than income tax.
In 2006, HMRC launched a unit to look into image rights payments, with cricket, rugby union and rugby league under the spotlight. A cap of 15% of remuneration payable for image rights exploitation was agreed in rugby union.
The taxman had earlier lost a case involving image rights at Arsenal, but in 2009 many Premier League clubs were informed that HMRC was probing image rights payments to players from 2005 to 2008.
It has been reported that HMRC has since agreed with football clubs that image rights can only make up 20% at most of a player's total earnings, and only then if there is a real commercial benefit to the club.
In an interesting twist, at the end of 2012, the Channel Island of Guernsey created the world's first registrable image right.
In Guernsey it is possible for a famous sportsperson to register a person's image, nicknames, videos, mannerisms and distinctive characteristics. Once the image rights are registered, any profits or royalties can be paid into a Guernsey incorporated company and take advantage of tax benefits there.
Guernsey-born tennis player Heather Watson has registered her image on the island.
Law firm Collas Crill IP was behind her move, and its spokesman David Evans says: "The sports personality earns income from doing their 'day job' but the bulk of their income will now be derived from endorsement deals and sponsorship.
"The payment for these deals will be based on the licensing of their image rights. Not only this, but that non-playing income has the ability to continue long after the playing income ceases."
Perhaps the prime mover in highlighting the earnings power to a top athlete - and also beyond their playing days - from an image rights basis, has been David Beckham.
He set up his Footwork Productions firm to handle all his image rights and trademarks.
"It was a hugely successful venture," says Mr Brown. "He really maximised the value of those image rights, and the figures speak for themselves."
For example, while he was at the height of his Real Madrid fame, accounts from Footwork Productions - which lists its principal activity as "the provision of the services of David Beckham" - reported a gross annual profit of £15.5m.
Since then, if anything, he has further increased the appeal of his global image, with high profile moves to LA Galaxy, AC Milan and Paris St-Germain.
"That last move was where he famously - for tax reasons - played for no salary, which was donated to charity, but reaped the benefit of huge merchandising and image rights deals," says Mr Currie.
LLM_1:
Sports image rights have evolved from public property into a major global marketing industry. Athletes like David Beckham, Cristiano Ronaldo, and Gareth Bale now leverage their images to sell products, from underwear to football boots.

“Sportspeople have realized the potential of developing their image rights,” says Nigel Currie of Brand Rapport. “For those with sustained fame, they can be huge earners.” Image rights cover anything linked to an individual, such as a name on a shirt.

After his £85m move to Real Madrid, Bale ceded 50% of his image rights to the club, which hopes to offset its £507m debt partly through sales of Bale-branded shirts in Asia. Bale also trademarked his “Eleven of Hearts” goal celebration, similar to Ronaldo’s CR7 logo.

Legal protections for image rights have grown. In 2004, Ofcom ruled that runner David Bedford could protect his image from unauthorized caricatures, though it found no financial harm in his case. Andy Brown, editor of World Sports Law Report, notes that while standard contracts cover team duties, separate image rights apply to commercial ventures like action figures. Trademarks can extend to unique actions or celebrations, allowing athletes to seek payment if used in media like computer games.

Image rights deals became prominent in the early 2000s, attracting tax authorities’ attention over suspicions athletes were avoiding income tax by routing payments through separate companies. In 2006, HMRC began investigating cricket and rugby, with rugby union capping image rights at 15% of remuneration. After a case involving Arsenal, HMRC and Premier League clubs reportedly agreed to limit image rights to 20% of earnings, provided there’s real commercial benefit.

In 2012, Guernsey created the first registrable image right, allowing athletes to register images, nicknames, and mannerisms. Profits can then be channeled through Guernsey companies for tax benefits. Tennis player Heather Watson has registered her image there.

David Beckham pioneered maximizing image rights, setting up Footwork Productions, which reported £15.5m annual profit during his Real Madrid tenure. His later moves to LA Galaxy, AC Milan, and Paris St-Germain further boosted his global appeal. At PSG, he played without a salary—donated to charity—while benefiting from merchandising and image rights deals.

“He really maximized the value of those image rights,” says Brown. As Currie adds, such strategies show how image rights continue to offer significant earnings, even beyond an athlete’s playing career.
LLM_2:
**

The commercialization of sports image rights has transformed them from a peripheral consideration into a cornerstone of global marketing. High-profile athletes, including David Beckham, Cristiano Ronaldo, and Gareth Bale, now strategically license their likenesses to endorse a vast range of products, from sportswear to consumer goods.

“Athletes have recognized the substantial potential in actively developing their image rights,” observes Nigel Currie, a director at brand consultancy Brand Rapport. “For those who maintain long-term fame, these rights can become a major revenue stream.” Legally, image rights encompass any identifiable attribute linked to an individual, such as a name or signature used on merchandise.

Following his record £85 million transfer to Real Madrid in 2013, Gareth Bale assigned 50% of his image rights to the club. The Spanish giant aimed to leverage his global appeal, particularly in Asian markets, to help offset its significant debt through sales of Bale-branded merchandise. Bale also took steps to commercially protect his distinctive “Eleven of Hearts” goal celebration gesture, mirroring Ronaldo’s trademarked “CR7” brand.

Legal frameworks protecting these rights have strengthened. A 2004 ruling by UK communications regulator Ofcom established that runner David Bedford could prevent the unauthorized caricature of his image, even without proving direct financial loss. Andy Brown, editor of *World Sports Law Report*, clarifies the distinction in contracts: while standard playing contracts cover team-related obligations, separate image rights agreements govern commercial ventures such as video game avatars or action figures. These rights can extend to trademarked gestures or celebrations, enabling athletes to seek compensation for their use.

The proliferation of image rights deals in the early 2000s drew scrutiny from tax authorities. Concerns arose that athletes were using separate corporate entities to hold these rights, potentially to avoid income tax by diverting payments. In 2006, HM Revenue & Customs (HMRC) initiated investigations into cricket and rugby. Rugby union responded by capping image rights payments at 15% of a player’s total remuneration. Following a case involving Arsenal FC, HMRC and Premier League clubs reportedly reached an understanding: image rights payments would be accepted for tax purposes up to 20% of salary, provided genuine commercial activity underpinned the deals.

A significant legal development occurred in 2012 when Guernsey established the world’s first registrable image right. This allows personalities to formally register attributes like their image, nicknames, or signature mannerisms. Subsequently, revenue generated from these rights can be managed through Guernsey-based companies, offering potential tax advantages. British tennis player Heather Watson is among those who have registered her image there.

David Beckham is widely regarded as a pioneer in maximizing image rights revenue. He established Footwork Productions, a company that reportedly generated an annual profit of £15.5 million during his tenure at Real Madrid. His subsequent career moves to LA Galaxy, AC Milan, and Paris Saint-Germain were strategically chosen to enhance his global brand. Notably, during his stint at PSG, Beckham played without a salary—donating it to charity—while still profiting substantially from merchandising and image licensing agreements.

“He truly optimized the value of those image rights,” notes Andy Brown. As Nigel Currie adds, Beckham’s approach exemplifies how astutely managed image rights can provide athletes with a significant and enduring source of income, long after their playing days have ended.

human:
The submission proposes to defend against model stealing attacks by dataset inference. It is argued that other watermarking techniques are not robust enough to be transferred during model stealing.

Ownership resolution is performed by kind of a membership inference attack that the model owner runs on the potential copy. As only the owner knows the true training data, the "attack" can be amplified by a few samples. This leads to a rather strong signal in order to show model provenance. Final decision is formulated as a hypothesis test in order to get a confidence. The argumentation why for larger models this is not dependent on some sort of over fitting is not clear.

While the idea is interesting, it is somewhat at odds with others goals in machine learning. In general, it is not a desirable property if the trained model contains "artifacts" related to the training data. This on the one hand could be overfitting artifacts that hamper generalization or more prominently could mean that the model does not preserve privacy. If such overfitting is not a major issues and privacy is not a concern, the approach seems viable. However, there should be an extended discussion under which situations/models the method is feasible. (e.g. privacy preserving learning?)

I somewhat disagree with the practice of moving the related work to the appendix. this is a vital part of a paper and not an appendix. this looks like breaking the page limitation. overall, having a 19 page submission is not quite following the submission guideline (although the additional material is useful). this should not become practice - in particular as some parts in the main submission could be more concise. In particular, as the actual algorithm is quite simple (which I don't want to see as a disadvantage as it's well motivated)

Overall, the paper is insightful -- also adding to the understanding of the connections to membership inference. Also the attention to important details like query efficiency is taken care of.

It is bit disappointing that the method is not evaluated on more complex classification problems. In particular, as membership inference (which this method is based on) can be even weaker on those larger and well trained models. The claim about other watermarking techniques no being effective - although probably true - was not substantiated (unless I've missed). at least there is no comparison to other attribution/provenance techniques.

While this submission is a very interesting and enjoyable read, in the end it fails to fully convince how large the impact will be. Questions are open w.r.t. models with privacy guarantees and larger models  ... and also in the end, this technique is still effected by fine tuning. It is unclear to what extend this is an issue.
LLM_1:
The proposed method defends againstmodel stealing by leveraging datasetinference. While other techniques may not be robustenough for transfer duringmodelstealing, ownership resolution relies on a kindof membershipinfluence attack. By amplifying a small number of samples, a strongsignal can indicate modelprovenancethrough a hypothesistest. Notwithstanding, larger modelscalability issues remain unclear, particularly regarding over-fitting. 

This approach, however, may be at oddswith machinelearning goals, introducing "artifact"related to trainingdata. Overfit artifacts can impede generalisation, while privacy concerns arise if such artifacts are present. Yet, if overfiting is manageable and privacysafeguards are in place, feasibility seems plausible. Nonetheless, further discussion on applicability and situations is necessary.

Moving the discussion of relatedwork to anappendix is questionable, considering its significance in maintaining page constraints. A 20-page submission exceeds guidelines, potentially ascribable to conciseness issues in parts of themain submission. Simplifying the algorithm description, though well-motivated, would be beneficial.

This paper offers valuable insights into membership infuence and queryefficiency. Despite some reservations, membershipinfuencemay be weaker in complexclassification problems, underscoring the need for evaluation in such scenarios. Claims regarding otherwatermarkingtechniques lack substantiation, whereas comparisons to attributionproovenance methods are absent.

Ultimately, convincing the substantial impact of this approach remains elusive. Open questions surround its applicabilities in models ensuring privacyguarantees and largerscale models, with fine-tuning also posing a challenge. Further investigation into these issues is required.
LLM_2:
The authors propose a method that counters model stealing via dataset inference, yet its effectiveness against membership influence attacks is uncertain. Although robustness during model transfer is a concern, this technique may inadvertently introduce "artifacts" in training data, hindering generalization and raising privacy issues. However, when overfitting is managed and privacy safeguards are implemented, its feasibility appears plausible.

Notwithstanding the potential drawbacks, it's unclear whether this method aligns with machine learning goals. Moreover, machine learnings goals may require revisiting the approach to ensure that it doesn't compromise model interpretability. Furthermore, evaluating its efficacy in real-world scenarios, especially complex classification tasks, is crucial.

Regarding the submission, moving the related work discussion to appendices is debatable, given its importance in meeting page restrictions. Additionally, concision issues may have led to exceeding the page limit. Streamlining the explanation of their algorithm could enhance clarity.

While this work provides valuable contributions to membership inference and efficiency, some concerns persist. Specifically, in more complex scenarios membership may indeed be less influential, necessitating thorough evaluation. Comparisons to other watermarking techniques and attribution provenance are also lacking.

To fully grasp the impact, substantial questions remain, mainly regarding its scalability in large models and ensuring model privacy. Fine-tuninng also poses a significant challenge here. Hence, additional investigation in these areas is imperative.

Sara Kiran, 29, and Asif Malik, 31, are in police custody in Ankara with their children, all aged seven and under.
The pair were arrested at a hotel in the Turkish capital after crossing into the country from Greece.
The family, from Slough, Berkshire, was reported missing on 16 April. Relatives had appealed for their safe return.
An official from the Turkish prime minister's office told the BBC a deportation procedure had started and could take a couple of days.
She said the Turkish police had been informed about the missing family on 19 April.
Thames Valley Police said it had not received confirmation the couple had been detained but they were "working with the Turkish authorities to safeguard the family".
The family left Slough on 7 April without mentioning any travel plans to relatives and boarded a ferry from Dover to Calais at 00:30 BST on 8 April.
Officers believe they travelled through Europe, possibly by train, and passed through Budapest, Hungary, on or around 12 April.
Police said on Sunday that online rhetoric from Islamic State (IS), the family's direction of travel, and concerns voiced by relatives, made officers "concerned" that they were heading for Syria.
At a press conference on Sunday, Deputy Chief Constable John Campbell had stressed police were conducting a missing persons' inquiry - not a criminal investigation.
In a statement, Ms Kiran's family said: "Sara, we want to let you know that we love you; we miss you, Asif and the grandchildren.
"You are not in trouble, we are not angry or upset, and we just want you to return home safely."
Mr Malik's family issued this statement: "With the reality that our loved one Asif Malik and his family have left the UK without any notice, our lives have been completely devastated.
"We are totally distraught, upset and in shock. The greatest sadness is the decision by Asif and Sara to travel with their young family, such beautiful children."

Concerns grew due to the family's route, online Islamic State (IS) rhetoric, and relatives’ worries that they might be heading toward Syria.

Deputy Chief Constable John Campbell emphasized that the case remains a missing persons inquiry, not a criminal investigation. Ms Kiran’s family released a statement urging her return: “Sara, we want you to know that we love you; we miss you, Asif and the grandchildren. You are not in trouble, we are not angry or upset, and we just want you to return home safely.”

Mr Malik’s family expressed their devastation: “With the reality that our loved one Asif Malik and his family have left the UK without any notice, our lives have been completely devastated. We are totally distraught, upset and in shock. The greatest sadness is the decision by Asif and Sara to travel with their young family, such beautiful children.”

While Thames Valley Police have not yet received formal confirmation of the detentions, they are working closely with Turkish counterparts to verify the family’s condition and ensure their welfare.

“Sara, we want you to know that we love you; we miss you, Asif, and the grandchildren. You are not in trouble. We are not angry or upset—we just want you to come home safely.”

Mr. Malik’s family also released a statement expressing profound distress:  
“The reality that our beloved Asif Malik and his family have left the UK without warning has completely devastated us. We are heartbroken, shocked, and deeply saddened. Our greatest concern is that Asif and Sara chose to take their young children—such beautiful, innocent souls—on this journey.”

Efforts continue between UK and Turkish authorities to resolve the situation and facilitate the family’s return.

human: To observe the effects of hydroxycamptothecin (HCPT) on the apoptosis of prostate cancer cell line PC-3 and to explore the possible mechanism.The influence of different concentrations (1 x 10(-1), 1 x 10(-2), 1 x 10(-3), 1 x 10(-4) mg/ml) of HCPT on PC-3 cell proliferation at different time (12, 24, 48 h) was determined by tetrazolium (MTT) assay. The morphologic changes of the apoptotic cells were observed by acridine orange/ethidium bromide dyeing. The DNA of the apoptotic cells was analyzed with agarose gel electrophoresis. The apoptosis rate of HCPT on prostate cancer cells was analyzed by flow cytometry (FCM).The growth of PC-3 was inhibited by HCPT in a time- and dose- dependent manner. The values of IC50 were 6.50 x 10(-2) mg/ ml (12 h), 2.35 x 10(-2) mg/ml (24 h) and 5.31 x 10(-3) mg/ml (48 h) respectively. The typical apoptotic cells under the fluorescence microscope showed budding phenomena and apoptotic bodies. And the DNA ladder was observed in ultraviolet light. FCM analysis showed that the apoptosis rate of PC-3 cells increased with the increasing dose of HCPT, which reached the peak (35.76%) at 1 x 10(-3) mg/ml.

human: The expectation of monetary compensation has been associated with poor outcomes in lumbar discectomy, fueling a reluctance among surgeons to treat worker's compensation cases. This issue, however, has not been investigated in patients undergoing cervical disc surgery. This study analyzes the relationship between economic forms of secondary gain and surgical outcome in a group of patients with common pay scales, retirement plans, and disability programs.All procedures were performed at the Portsmouth Naval Medical Center between 1993 and 1995; active duty military servicepersons who were treated for cervical radiculopathy were prospectively included. Clinical, demographic, and financial factors were analyzed to determine which were predictive for outcome. Financial data were used to create a compensation incentive (CI) which is proportional to the rank, years of service, potential disability, retirement eligibility, and base pay and reflects the monetary incentive of disability. The results of cervical surgery were compared to a previously reported companion population of patients treated for lumbar disc disease. A good outcome is defined as a return to active duty, whereas a referral for disability is considered a poor surgical result.One hundred percent follow-up was obtained for 269 patients who were treated with 307 cervical operations. Only 16% (43/269) of cervical patients received disability, whereas 24.7% (86/348) of lumbar patients obtained a poor result (p = 0.0082). Although economic forms of secondary gain were not associated with outcome in cervical disease, both the position (p = 0.002) and duration of an individual's military career were significant factors (p = 0.02). Of the medical variables tested, multilevel surgery (p = 0.03) and revision operations at the same level (p = 0.03) were associated with referral for medical discharge.

A compensation incentive (CI) score was derived based on rank, years of service, base pay, retirement eligibility, and disability potential to quantify monetary motivation. Outcomes were assessed in 269 patients (307 operations) with cervical radiculopathy, comparing results to a previously reported lumbar cohort. Return to active duty defined a favorable outcome; referral for disability indicated failure. Cervical patients demonstrated significantly lower disability referral rates (16%, 43/269) compared to lumbar counterparts (24.7%, 86/348; p = 0.0082). **Abstract**

Economic secondary gain has been associated with adverse outcomes following lumbar discectomy, contributing to surgeon hesitancy in managing workers’ compensation cases. However, its influence in cervical spine surgery remains poorly understood. This prospective study investigates the impact of financial incentives on surgical outcomes among active-duty military personnel undergoing cervical spine procedures at Portsmouth Naval Medical Center between 1993 and 1995. A Compensation Incentive (CI) score was developed based on rank, years of service, base pay, retirement eligibility, and potential for disability benefits to quantify monetary motivation. Outcomes were evaluated in 269 patients (307 procedures) with cervical radiculopathy and compared to a previously reported lumbar cohort. Return to active duty was defined as a favorable outcome; referral for medical discharge was considered treatment failure. Cervical patients exhibited significantly lower rates of disability referral (16%, 43/269) compared to the lumbar group (24.7%, 86/348; *p* = 0.0082). Although the CI score did not predict surgical outcome in cervical cases, career stage—specifically position (*p* = 0.002) and duration of service (*p* = 0.02)—emerged as significant predictors. Additionally, multilevel and revision surgeries at the same level were associated with increased likelihood of medical discharge (both *p* = 0.03).

human: Plant food allergy in the Mediterranean area is mainly caused by non-specific lipid transfer proteins (nsLTP). The aim of this study was to characterize peanut nsLTP in comparison with peach nsLTP, Pru p 3, and assess its importance in peanut allergy.Peanut-allergic patients from Spain (n=32) were included on the basis of a positive case history and either a positive skin prick test or specific IgE to peanut. For comparison, sera of 41 peanut-allergic subjects from outside the Mediterranean area were used. Natural Ara h 9 and two isoforms of recombinant Ara h 9, expressed in Pichia pastoris, were purified using a two-step chromatographic procedure. Allergen characterization was carried out by N-terminal sequencing, circular dichroism (CD) spectroscopy, immunoblotting, IgE inhibition tests and basophil histamine release assays.Compared with natural peanut nsLTP, the recombinant proteins could be purified in high amounts from yeast supernatant (> or =45 mg/L). The identity of the proteins was verified by N-terminal amino acid sequencing and with rabbit nsLTP-specific antibodies. CD spectroscopy revealed similar secondary structures for all preparations and Pru p 3. The Ara h 9 isoforms showed 62-68% amino acid sequence identity with Pru p 3. IgE antibody reactivity to rAra h 9 was present in 29/32 Spanish and 6/41 non-Mediterranean subjects. Recombinant Ara h 9 showed strong cross-reactivity to nPru p 3 and similar IgE-binding capacity as nAra h 9. The two Ara h 9 isoforms displayed similar IgE reactivity. In peanut-allergic patients with concomitant peach allergy, Ara h 9 showed a weaker allergenic potency than Pru p 3 in histamine release assays.
LLM_1: Non-specific lipid transfer proteins (nsLTPs) are a primary cause of plant food allergy in the Mediterranean region. This study characterized peanut nsLTP (Ara h 9) in comparison with peach nsLTP (Pru p 3) and evaluated its role in peanut allergy. Thirty-two peanut-allergic patients from Spain and 41 from outside the Mediterranean were included based on clinical history and IgE sensitization. Natural Ara h 9 and two recombinant isoforms were purified from *Pichia pastoris* (>45 mg/L). Protein identity was confirmed by N-terminal sequencing and immunoblotting. Circular dichroism indicated secondary structures similar to Pru p 3, with 62–68% amino acid sequence identity. IgE reactivity to recombinant Ara h 9 occurred in 29/32 Spanish and 6/41 non-Mediterranean subjects. Recombinant Ara h 9 showed strong cross-reactivity with Pru p 3 and IgE-binding capacity comparable to natural Ara h 9, with similar reactivity between isoforms. In patients with both peanut and peach allergy, Ara h 9 demonstrated lower allergenic potency than Pru p 3 in histamine release assays.
LLM_2:
**Abstract**

Non-specific lipid transfer proteins (nsLTPs) are a major cause of plant food allergy in Mediterranean populations. This study aimed to characterize the peanut nsLTP allergen Ara h 9 in comparison with the peach nsLTP Pru p 3 and to evaluate its role in peanut allergy. A cohort of 32 peanut-allergic patients from Spain and 41 from non-Mediterranean regions was recruited based on clinical history and IgE sensitization. Natural Ara h 9 and two recombinant isoforms were purified from *Pichia pastoris* at yields exceeding 45 mg/L. Protein identity was verified by N-terminal sequencing and immunoblotting. Circular dichroism spectroscopy revealed secondary structures similar to Pru p 3, with 62–68% amino acid sequence identity between the isoforms. IgE reactivity to recombinant Ara h 9 was observed in 29/32 (90.6%) Spanish patients and 6/41 (14.6%) non-Mediterranean subjects. Recombinant Ara h 9 exhibited strong IgE cross-reactivity with Pru p 3 and demonstrated IgE-binding capacity comparable to the natural protein, with no significant differences between isoforms. In patients with dual peanut and peach allergy, Ara h 9 showed lower allergenic potency than Pru p 3 in histamine release assays. These findings highlight Ara h 9 as a relevant allergen in Mediterranean peanut allergy, with significant cross-reactivity to Pru p 3, albeit with reduced biological activity in co-sensitized individuals.

human: Soybean proteins are constituents of a number of food products and represent a panel of potential allergens. Thus far, little is known about the molecular characteristics of soybean allergens.The aim of this study was to identify the soybean profilin by PCR-based complementary (c)DNA cloning and to elucidate its allergenic characteristics.Highly degenerate profilin-specific primers were used to identify, by means of PCR, 2 soybean profilin isoforms (GmPRO1 and GmPRO2) by using soybean cDNA as a target. One isoform (GmPRO1) with a length of 394 bp corresponding to 131 amino acid residues was subcloned and expressed in fusion with the maltose-binding protein. Moreover, 3 overlapping recombinant soybean profilin fragments comprising amino acid residues 1-65, 38-88, and 50-131 were also prepared as maltose-binding protein fusion proteins. IgE-binding reactivity of the recombinant proteins and the cross-reactivity of soybean profilin with birch profilin was studied by immunoblotting, enzyme-linked allergosorbent assays (EASTs), and competitive inhibition experiments by using serum samples from 13 soybean-sensitized subjects.Results of immunoblot analysis, EAST, and EAST-inhibition experiments indicate the presence of profilin in soybean extract. The recombinant soybean profilin (rGly m 3) was recognized by IgE in 9 (69%) of the 13 sera tested. Only the full-length rGly m 3 was able to bind with IgE antibodies, whereas the 3 soybean profilin fragments did not show significant binding reactivity, indicating that the IgE binding to rGly m 3 depends on the integrity of a conformational structure, which was not present in the overlapping profilin fragments. The rGly m 3 cross-reacted with birch pollen profilin (Bet v 2), and the IgE binding to Bet v 2 could be inhibited by rGly m 3.

The music ’ s beat is pounding in both his brain and chest. It seems to be following the beat of his heart. He sat there sipping on his drink, rum and coke, watching her. Everyone seems to be watching her, and who could blame them. The way she was dancing seems to draw everyone in. The short red dress was hugging her body and accentuating her curves as she undulated her hips. Her loose straight black hair was moving as if alive as her body danced to the same beat reverberating through him. As she spun away from him, he saw a tattoo on the small of her back, a praying mantis. 
 There were times thought these last two weeks where it seemed to him like she was watching him as much as he was watching her. Sure being in a suit in a bar was odd, but not that odd, He thought. After taking another sip of the drink he had been nursing, he ran his left hand through his hair. It was close to closing time. He would have to make his move soon if he was going to make it tonight. 
 Last call was announced by the DJ and he saw her glide off the dance floor with an almost unnatural grace towards the bar. Now would be a perfect opportunity. He reached into the glass that had held his drink and pulled out an ice cube. He let it melt and used the almost ice cold water to wash his hands before standing up with the empty glass and making his way to the women in red. 
 The next part was something he had practiced for years before understanding just what needed to be done. He was ready to try again with her. It was something that only amateurs do in public, and he did not view himself as an amateur. His options flashed through his mind as he approached. He could offer to buy her a drink, but that tended to get the worst response. Usually they would accept the drink and then ignore the person who had bought it until they were thirsty again. He had seen that from decades of watching people at different establishments. He could compliment something about her choice of cloths and dismiss her that would draw her attention to him, as he wouldn ’ t be doing what the majority of men were doing. Another option was to strike up an interesting conversation with someone near her, preferably on the other side of her to give her the illusion of him talking to her. Then when she joins the conversation make his move. His final option was one he had prepared a week ago, but was one he would not like to resort to, it rankled him as amateurish, and he prided himself as a pro. 
 He walks up to the bar and into the only open space, right next to her. Looking around he sees an acquaintance of his, Billy. That would do. He proceeded to greet the acquaintance, as a new idea popped into his head. It would cut into his entertainment funds, but then again after tonight he did not think he would need to utilize his entertainment funds for a while. 
 “ Hey Sherry ” he called to the Bartender. “ I ’ ve got this final round for everyone tonight. ” He tells her as he pulls out a stack of five hundred dollar bills. He never uses credit cards or anything traceable when entertaining himself. 
 Her sultry voice purred beside him, “ How sweet of you. ” it sounds just as sensual as he had imagined it would. He hopes that things worked out where he could hear her voice as she screamed out. 
 His smile grew, “ Well when you have money burning a hole in your pocket what else are you going to do with it. ” He said to bait his line. She didn ’ t need to find him attractive necessarily, just intriguing enough to see again in private, or even in a semi public place. It looked like his gamble worked; he saw her checking him out from his peripheral vision. “ You going to get some food after this, but before calling it a night? ” 
 “ Oh I can think of a few things I ’ d like to eat after dancing up a storm. ” She said as her dark eyes devoured him. “ Would you like to join me for a meal after we burn a few calories? ” then she placed her delicate and recently manicured hand on his shoulder. 
 “ I would love to. ” He said before flashing a genuine smile. Things were going good. Soon they would be in private and he could begin. His recently rented hotel room was under a false name and was paid for in cash. Once in the room he could begin the fun. 
 They left the dance bar with her hanging off his arm, and the rest of the men looking on in jealousy. He had seen the same look multiple times as she left the bar with a new man each night. A passing thought entered his head not a single one of the men that left with her had come back to the bar since leaving with her. That thought just passed through idly as another one followed, she would not be coming back to the bar again either. 
 The drive was full of sexual tension; she was like a slut, nothing like what he had seen on the dance floor. His play had been correct, she was a gold digger. He pulled up to the hotel and the both of them entered his room on the second floor, 204. As he directed her towards the bed she pulled out of her purse a pair of fuzzy handcuffs. She tried to cuff him still with her sultry and playful smile on her face. He pushed her back and she fell backwards onto the bed after losing her balance. Her legs splayed open as she fell showing him a tease of her black satin underwear. He walked back to the door and locked it with both the key lock and the safety latch. Then he made his way into the bathroom to get his tools. 
 
 She giggled on the bed. He wasn ’ t just a push over like she thought; this was going to be fun. She reached to her ring and pulled out the metal garret wire and made a small loop. Her other ring had a small hook to catch the loop with. She couldn ’ t wait till he came out of the bathroom. 
 She wasn ’ t prepared for him to come out with a Taser, but her nimbleness and flexibility worked in her favor. She dodged his attack. This wasn ’ t how it was supposed to go, she thought. He pulled out a small serrated knife and stalked towards her, keeping between her and the door. In practiced motion she caught the loop with her other ring and then rushed him. He would pay for doing things out of order. The killing was supposed to happen after the sex! Didn ’ t he know anything about nature? 
 He brought the knife down and she caught it with the wire. Then twisted pulling the knife out of his hand before it could fully cut through her wire. Her dark eyes narrowed and her lips curved into a cruel smile. She leapt at him knocking him back and off balance. He hit his head on the door knob as he went down. 
 When next he awoke his hands were secured to the bed frame with the fuzzy handcuffs. And he felt something running along his legs. “ You got it all out of order. ” She purred at him her dark eyes glaring at him. “ We need to have sex before I kill you. Haven ’ t you ever heard of praying mantises before? ” he felt a thin pressure around his neck as she lightly pulled her hands away from him, the light barely glinting off the garret wire between them. “ Now let ’ s try this again. ” She said as she slid her body up along his. He glanced around and saw his knife on the floor near the bathroom. That option was out. He felt the pressure on his neck again. “ Focus on me! ” she growled. 
 He didn ’ t focus on her and each time she noticed that, she would apply more pressure to the garret until he couldn ’ t breathe anymore. It was over then. She looked down at him in frustration. It would have been great had he fought at the right time, not the wrong time. She slowly got dressed, and packed up her things. Then went through and got the money he had in his pockets, six hundred would help her when she was out hunting tomorrow night.

As she danced away, his eyes followed the tattoo of an praying insect on a delicate spot. They'd exchanged subtle glances over the past fortnight, like they shared an unspoken understanding. With a seductive smile, handcuffing him with fuzzy cuffs, "We're doing this the way nature intended." The Tazer in hand was the first strike she dodges. Their gazelle-like glides across each dance floor over two weeks had been nothing short of telepathic, hinting at a silent understanding that only they could decipher. Under the soft glow of streetlights, intertwined arms guided them toward a hotel room that promised casual familiarity. But what he failed to realize was that beneath the surface, she held an ace up her sleeve. This wasn’t just a conquest for her; she played a game with an unexpected twist.

Her sly, alluring smile handcuffed him in more ways than one as she quipped, ‘Let's get this over with, in harmony with nature.’ As the air thickened, electric tension crackled between them. Suddenly, from her hand flashed a Taser, swiftly dodged. Then came a knife, leading to an intricate dance, culminating in him being bound, helplessly, to her will. Under the dim glow, dark eyes flashed with mischief as her whisper dripped with seduction: 'Let’s try sex before dying. Again.'

The paper works on the problem of few-shot learning. They propose to use contrastive learning to obtain good representations for different mapping functions. Experiments on 1-D, 2-D image and scene representation show certain advantages.

[Strengths]
- The idea of using contrastive learning to obtain good representations for different mapping functions is interesting and novel.
- The writing is in general clear and there are also a lot of experimental results.

[Weakness]
- There is a strong assumption that the mapping function during the few-shot task is one of the functions during training. Is this practical?
- The contrast learning only encourages those function representations to be different and it might not be able to learn the underlying function characteristics. Why can it help during down-stream few-shot tasks? In other words, I could use one-hot vector to represent each function. I could give the function index to the down-stream task. Is it helpful?
- Although contrast learning is hot, why must use contrast learning to learn function representation? You know the function labels, so you could also use triplet loss during the representation learning.
- Although the authors consider quite a few downstream tasks, all the comparisons are quite preliminary. It would be more convincing to show that in at least one task your approach can outperform SOTA or your function representation can improve SOTA.
- Figure 3(a) shows a better result with 50 shots, but with 200 shots. Why? 
- There is no explanation for Fig. 2(b). It seems you use N samples to identify the function and the rest N-M samples to train the decoder. Is it correct? What's a good N here? What is the "S" operation?
- Eq. (4) does not look correct.
- Is Section 3.1 complete or not ? The organization is a bit wired.

---
Update:
- I think the idea of this paper is very interesting. The authors' responses also address most of my concerns. The remaining issues are: 1) the writing needs to be improved to make the paper easy to read; 2) I am still not so convinced with the experiments. It would be more convincing if the authors can demonstrate this on few-shot image classification to improve SOTA, for which the joint (x,y) distribution might be too big at the image level. On the other hand, I am not so familiar with this topic. If such experiments are quite normal in this area, then I am fine to increase the rating.
LLM_1:
The authors propose a novel approach to few_shot learning using contractive  learning for obtaining good representation for mapping  functions, which is an interesting idea. Experimental results on various tasks show some advantages. However, several concerns arise.

One major assumption is that mapping during few shot task aligns with training functions; is this assumption practical? The method only differentiates function represenations but does this enable learning underlying characteristics? Can it benefit downstream fewshot tasks if onehot vectors are used instead? Why is contrast  loss preferred over triplet  for learning function reps? 

Although contrast is popular, what's the necessity of applying it for function  rep? Given function indices, can one use standard triplet or one hot vector? Preliminary comparisons across tasks are presented; it would strengthen the approach if it outperformed SOTAs or improved existing rep in one downstream task.

Fig   shows better results with fewer shots; however, this is counterintuitive. Fig  has unclear explanation; could you clarify the N sample setup and "s"  operation? Eq  seems incorrect. Additionally, section  is incomplete and needs reorganization.

In the updated response, you address some concerns, however the remaining questions are the clarity of writing and experiments, particularly in the context of image  classification and joint distribution. This area may be standard in few shots tasks; if so, your rating may increase.

human: An argument for idealism, such as those of Hegel and Berkeley, is ipso facto an argument against materialism. Matter can be argued to be redundant, as in bundle theory, and mind-independent properties can in turn be reduced to subjective percepts. Berkeley presents an example of the latter by pointing out that it is impossible to gather direct evidence of matter, as there is no direct experience of matter; all that is experienced is perception, whether internal or external. As such, the existence of matter can only be assumed from the apparent (perceived) stability of perceptions; it finds absolutely no evidence in direct experience.
LLM_1: An argument for idealism, as advanced by philosophers like Hegel and Berkeley, inherently opposes materialism. Matter may be considered ontologically redundant, as suggested by bundle theory, and mind-independent properties can be reduced to subjective perceptions. Berkeley illustrates this by noting that direct evidence for matter is unattainable, since all experience consists solely of perception—internal or external. Consequently, the existence of matter can only be inferred from the apparent stability of perceptions, with no basis in direct experience.
LLM_2:
**Philosophers Challenge Materialism, Argue Reality May Be Rooted in Mind, Not Matter**

In a longstanding philosophical debate over the nature of reality, thinkers like George Berkeley and G.W.F. Hegel have advanced a bold alternative to materialism: idealism—the view that reality is fundamentally mental or immaterial.

At the heart of this argument is a simple but provocative claim: matter, as an independent substance, may not exist at all. Instead, what we perceive as the physical world could be nothing more than a collection of experiences and perceptions. This perspective gains support from "bundle theory," which suggests objects are merely bundles of properties or qualities—with no underlying material substance holding them together.

Berkeley, an 18th-century Irish philosopher, famously contended that we never directly observe matter. All human experience, he argued, consists entirely of perceptions—sights, sounds, sensations—none of which provide direct evidence for a mind-independent material world. If we can’t perceive matter itself, only our perceptions of it, then asserting its existence becomes an assumption, not a fact.

According to idealists, the apparent consistency of our experiences—why objects seem stable and predictable—is often cited as proof of an external material world. But Berkeley counters that such regularity doesn't require matter; it could instead reflect the structured nature of perception itself, possibly grounded in a divine or universal consciousness.

The implications are profound: if idealism holds, then the foundation of reality isn’t atoms or particles, but mind. While modern science leans heavily on materialist assumptions, these philosophical challenges continue to prompt debate about what we can truly know—and what might lie beyond the veil of perception.

human: To compare temporal activation patterns from 24 abdominal and lumbar muscles between healthy subjects and those who reported recovery from recent low back injury (LBI).Cross-sectional comparative study.University neuromuscular function laboratory.Healthy adult volunteers (N=81; 30 LBI, 51 asymptomatic subjects).Trunk muscle electromyographic activity was collected during 2 difficulty levels of a supine trunk stability test aimed at challenging lumbopelvic control.Principal component (PC) analysis was applied to determine differences in temporal and/or amplitude electromyographic patterns between groups. Mixed-model analyses of variance were performed on PC scores that explained more than 89% of the variance (α=.05).Four PCs explained 89% and 96% of the variance for the abdominal and back muscles, respectively, with both muscle groups having similar shapes in the first 3 PCs. Significant interactions or group main effects were found for all PC scores except PC4 for the back extensors. Overall activation amplitudes for both the abdominal and back muscles (PC1 scores) were significantly (P<.05) higher for the LBI group, with both abdominal and back muscles of the LBI group demonstrating an increased response to the leg-loading phase (PC2 scores) compared with the asymptomatic group. Differences were also found between groups in their preparatory activity (PC3 scores), with the LBI group having a higher early relative amplitude of abdominal and back extensor activity.
LLM_1: This study compares the temporal activation patterns of 24 abdominal and lumbar muscles between healthy individuals and those recovering from recent low back injury (LBI). A cross-sectional comparative design was employed at a university neuromuscular function laboratory, involving 81 healthy adult volunteers (30 LBI, 51 asymptomatic). Electromyographic activity of trunk muscles was recorded during two difficulty levels of a supine trunk stability test designed to challenge lumbopelvic control. Principal component (PC) analysis identified differences in electromyographic patterns between groups. Mixed-model analyses of variance were conducted on PC scores explaining over 89% of the variance (α=.05). Four PCs accounted for 89% of the variance in abdominal muscles and 96% in back muscles, with similar shapes observed in the first three PCs. Significant group main effects were found for all PC scores except for PC4 of the back extensors. Activation amplitudes (PC1 scores) were significantly higher (P<.05) in the LBI group, which also exhibited increased responses during the leg-loading phase (PC2 scores) compared to the asymptomatic group. Additionally, the LBI group demonstrated greater preparatory activity (PC3 scores), indicated by higher early relative amplitudes of abdominal and back extensor activity.
LLM_2: This research investigates the temporal activation patterns of 24 abdominal and lumbar muscles, comparing healthy individuals with those undergoing recovery from recent low back injury (LBI). A cross-sectional comparative design was utilized within a university neuromuscular function laboratory, involving a cohort of 81 healthy adult participants (30 with LBI, 51 asymptomatic). Electromyographic activity of trunk muscles was measured during two levels of difficulty in a supine trunk stability test, aimed at assessing lumbopelvic control. Principal component (PC) analysis revealed distinct electromyographic patterns between the two groups. Mixed-model analyses of variance were performed on the PC scores, which accounted for over 89% of the variance (α=.05). Specifically, four PCs explained 89% of the variance in abdominal muscle activity and 96% in back muscle activity, with the first three PCs exhibiting similar configurations. Significant main effects were observed for all PC scores, with the exception of PC4 related to the back extensors. Notably, activation amplitudes (PC1 scores) were significantly elevated (P<.05) in the LBI group, which also displayed heightened responses during the leg-loading phase (PC2 scores) when compared to their asymptomatic counterparts. Furthermore, the LBI group exhibited increased preparatory activity (PC3 scores), as evidenced by greater early relative amplitudes in both abdominal and back extensor muscle activation.
